The scanned image data may be transferred from a first computer (14) associated with the scanner to a second computer (20) at a remote location. An analysis of the at least one characteristic is conducted based on the image data. The process further includes determining a diagnosis of at least one condition of the external portion, and/or at least one feature of the product applied to the external portion. The process may also involve determining a recommendation of a treatment for the condition and providing this recommendation. In addition, the process may include monitoring of the status of the external body portion during treatment. <IMAGE>

title: ADAPTIVELY ADJUSTED OPTICAL CORRELATOR AND METHOD
abstract: Field of the invention The This invention relates to optical image processors or correlator systems, the coherent light use, spatial Light modulators and Fourier transform optics, to process information or recognize patterns. Description of related prior art It has long been known that two-dimensional, spatial Fourier transform techniques can be used to Process images. For example, pattern recognition often becomes by working with the Fourier transform of a spatially varying Image, in contrast to the original image, relieved. In particular, generate optical correlators the two-dimensional correlation of an input image to a reference picture. A high level of correlation at one localized area within the image frame shows a detection of the reference image in this area. The correlation function is easiest by multiplying the Fourier transform a picture in the frequency domain with a "filter" performed what a frequency domain representation a reference picture or pictures. The resulting (two-dimensional) Frequency function will then return transformed to the spatial domain. Although such processing can be done digitally, it can do much faster through an optical Fourier transform of the Image performed become. Such high-speed image processing finds numerous applications in various fields, such as Safety, aviation, biomedical diagnostics and artificial Intelligence. Optical correlators using two-dimensional Fourier transform optics and active electronic spatial light modulators (SLMs) have been used to perform two-dimensional high-speed pattern recognition. For example, U.S. Patent No. 5,311,359 to Lucas et al. Describes an optical correlator system having a source of coherent light and a plurality of active and passive optical components disposed along a folded zigzag optical path. The active optical components are an input SLM, a filter SLM and a pixel-like photodetector (usually a CCD device); each of these active elements is typically a field of electronically addressable, active pixels arranged in a two-dimensional matrix. The passive components include reflective focusing mirrors and polarizers. In the patented device, the optical path is a tunnel contained within a block of transparent ceramics having an extremely low temperature expansion coefficient (7 × 10-H/ ° C). 1illustrates the prior art optical correlator of the Lucas patent, in which a coherent electromagnetic radiation source (typically a laser) is used.10that are inside a solid, optical support body12is arranged, a collimated and polarized, coherent radiation beam14generated. The spotlight14meets a pixel-like, reflective input SLM16and will, by whatever pattern, electronically on the input SLM16considered, modulated. The modulation is spatially distributed. As discussed in the patent, when a magneto-optic SLM is used, the pixels of the SLM are individually electronically modulated to permit rotation of the polarization of the reflected light as a function of the input signal addressed to that pixel cause. Such an SLM also requires an input polarizer and output polarizer that work as an analyzer (not in FIG1shown). The result is that some pixels of the field effectively absorb more while others reflect more, as a function of the electronic modulating pattern that is applied. The modulated beam14is reflected and propagated to a first, focusing mirror18, The beam14is from the first, focusing mirror18is reflected and applied to a filter SLM20focused. Provided that the first focusing mirror18has the correct focal length to the input SLM16on the filter SLM20It is a well-known consequence of the wave optics that the image is at the plane of the filter SLM20optically by a spatial Fourier transform into a frequency domain representation F (u, v) of the input image f (x, y) (where x and y are the spatial coordinates of the input SLM16and u and v are the spatial coordinates of the filter SLM20are) is transformed. It must be understood that the Fourier transform, which is referenced throughout, is a Fourier transform of a function (intensity of modulation) coincident with the position (in this case the position on the face of the input SLM16) varies. This Fourier transform of a spatially varying function should not be confused with the Fourier transform of a time varying function that is more familiar to engineers. The flat surfaces of the SLMs will actually present functions that vary in two dimensions; consequently, the transformed image will be a two-dimensional Fourier transform representing the frequency components of a two-dimensional image in two dimensions. The Fourier transformed image attached to the filter SLM20The filter is typically the previously obtained Fourier transform of a particular reference and therefore consists of a pattern of frequency components listed on a two-dimensional surface An input image to a reference image may be obtained by using the product of the Fourier transformed input image and the Fourier transformed reference image, as described in the prior art patent The product F (u, v) .H (u, v) (where H (u, v) is the filter) is then passed through a second focusing mirror22on a photodetector24focused. The resulting image on the photodetector24is the Fourier transform of the product image, which gives the correlation of the input image to the reference image (with an inverse of x and y coordinates at the detector). The correlation of the input function and the filter function thus appears on the photodetector24as a two-dimensional, correlated, optical intensity function. The previous correlator described above must be precisely optically aligned for best operation. The optical components comprising the input SLM16, the filter SLM20, the photodetector24and the mirrors18and22, must be in an optical alignment with the beam14to be adjusted. The necessary adjustments require great precision and accuracy to bring the assembly into optimal optical alignment. The alignment, once aligned, is often difficult to maintain as it is affected by thermally induced stresses applied to the optical device and the coherent light source. Mechanical stress and vibration induced stress can also cause undesirable misalignment effects. The most critical alignment in the earlier correlators is, as Lucas has recognized, the adjustment of the position of the filter SLM20relative to the input SLM16, This setting is critical in the geometry of the Lucas patent. The patented correlator lists a specific spatial frequency component of the input image to a specific point in the focal plane of the first focusing mirror18on. For proper operation, each specific input image frequency component must be further modulated (multiplied) by the specific, corresponding filter frequency component. This requires the specific frequency components of the input image to be specific pixels of the filter SLM20be listed. For the best operation, even a more stringent condition must be met: the specific frequency component of the input image must be listed at the center of the corresponding filter pixel. This requires that the position of the filter SLM20in x, y and z directions relative to the input SLM16must be adjusted, the accuracy is typically on the order of a few microns. In the earlier, Optical correlators make it difficult to precisely position the input and filter SLMs. Their position, once positioned, is difficult with regard to unavoidable mechanical and thermal stresses and changes to maintain in the ambient conditions. In the preferred embodiment, the invention employs independent beam deflection and feedback systems on multiple axes, preferably perpendicular to each other, which allows correction of the correlator in, for example, both the x and y directions as indicated in FIGS3and4, allows. The independent orientations should preferably be performed individually and sequentially, for example, first an x-shake and then a y-shake, under the control of the digital computer36, 8thFigure 10 illustrates in greater detail an embodiment of a complete correlator system of the invention comprising functional blocks100of the computer, interface electronics102and an optical correlator arrangement104, The functional computer blocks100can be in a software through the digital computer36or equivalent, logic circuits are executed. A data transfer sequencing logic106controls the overall timing, ignoring occasional frames for adaptive alignment, while maintaining the full throughput of the optical correlator for normal operation. The data transfer sequencing logic106also generates at least one digital dither signal. Preferably, two separate digital dither signals are applied to two reversible counters: counters108for trembling in the x direction and counters110for the trembling in the y direction. The outputs of the counters108and110get into an analog voltage through digital-to-analog converter (DACs)112and114converted and to interface electronics102comprising an inverter and summing amplifier circuits (described below), which in turn comprise the beam deflection device34drive. At the same time, this dither signal is sent to the beam deflection device34applied, the input test pattern and the frequency domain reference pattern are applied to the input SLM16 'and the filter SLM20 ', respectively, by an SLM and  CCD control logic block115(preferably executed by the digital computer36). The entire matrix of output levels is converted and becomes the digital computer36entered. The maximum amplitude detection logic118(preferably through the digital computer36is executed) compares the digitized photodetector output values corresponding to each individual pixel on the matrix of the photodetector24 'and finds the highest value on the matrix of the photodetector. This value is assigned to the peak correlation point. The position of the output peak, and hence the pixel address of the peak, may vary slightly during adjustment. The two peak values, one corresponding to each phase of the jitter, are detected and stored. Dual values (for each dimension) are then passed through functional comparator blocks120(for the x-correction) and122(for the y-correction) compared. If the orientation of the optical device deviates from the optimum, the double stored values for that dimension will be unequal and the appropriate functional comparator block120or122will generate a correction signal that is either positive or negative. The correction signal passing through the functional comparator blocks120and122is output, the direction of a count for reversible counter108(x-channel) and110(y channel). The reversible counters count pulses generated by the data transfer sequencing logic106generated for this purpose. The outputs of the reversible counter108and110containing the current position information for the actuator field32are held by DACs112and114(one for each channel), which produces duplicate analogue correction voltages: one for the x-direction, one for the y-direction. The manner of applying the correction voltages will depend on the specific geometry and characteristics of the beam deflection device34and a wide variety of arrangements are possible. The8thand9represent only one such possibility. In the embodiment shown, the beam deflection device sets34electromechanical actuators140.142.146and148which are positioned on diagonals relative to the x, y coordinate system and together form an actuator field. Inverting amplifiers124and126generate complementary signals by inverting the analog correction voltages. The analog correction voltages and the complementary signals then become in a cross-connected network of summing amplifiers130.132.134and138summed up to return control voltages158.160.162and164to create. These feedback control voltages in turn generate suitable x and y correction movements of the electromechanical actuators. In the embodiment which is in8th2, the feedback drive voltages are converted in a movement in the actuator field by extending or reducing oppositely positioned piezoelectric segments. For example, to move the deflector in the negative x direction, the segments would140and142be contracted while the segments146and148would be extended. 9In more detail, illustrates an actuator field included in the beam deflection device34of the invention can be used. The entire field (beam deflection device34) is composed of four actuators arranged in quadrants, each shaped like an arcuate quarter section, and all four together forming a broken ring. Each arcuate quarter section preferably comprises a plurality of piezoelectric layers154stacked in a laminar fashion that together form an actuator. Every piezoelectric layer154is preferably formed of a piezoelectric ceramic material. In the side cross section, which is in9can be represented, two actuator segments142and146be seen. electrode layers156, preferably metallized, are between each pair of piezoelectric layers154interposed. Alternating electrode layers156of the actuator146are with the feedback control voltage158connected; Similar are alternating electrode layers of the actuator142with the feedback control voltage160connected. actuators148and140not in9are shown are connected analogously. The stacking of the multilayer piezoelectric material allows greater elongation and shortening in response to an applied voltage. The Use of piezoelectric ceramic actuators is sufficient known and described in numerous sources. See for example Piezoelectric Ceramics, J. van Randeraat (Publications Dept., Ferroxcube Corporation, Saugerties, N.Y. 1974). Piezoelectric, ceramic Materials or actuators are widely available commercially, for example from Aura Ceramics (Minneapolis, MN), Polytec PI, Piezo System Jena (Germany), or Philips Electronic Components (available in USA over Signetics Corp., Sunnyvale, CA). In the embodiment illustrated in FIG3, the actuator field works9as a beam deflection device, by the laser arrangement30relative to the optical support body12 'is moved. In this embodiment, the laser arrangement is30firmly on the beam deflection device32mounted, which in turn is movable on the optical support body12 'is attached. Applying a voltage to the actuators of the beam deflection device34the actuators lengthen or contract as necessary to thereby cause the laser to collapse30to move and the beam14 'distract. It will be readily appreciated that other arrangements enabling beam deflection are possible, either by electromechanical actuators or by other devices. Beam deflection can be easily made by moving a mirror, a lens, a fiber optic coupling, or a prism, as an example, as opposed to moving the light source, as described above. A distraction could easily be done by moving a focusing mirror18 ', for example, be made. These and other methods of deflecting the beam are also within the scope of the invention. It is only necessary that the beam deflector provide sufficiently fine control, preferably so as to align the transformation image with the filter SLM20 'within less than a pixel diameter of a filter SLM. In some applications, the apparatus and method described above may be used to dynamically align a working optical correlator in the following manner: during normal operation of an optical correlator, alignment must be occasionally tested. Alignment can be accomplished with only a very small interruption to the normal operations of the correlator. During performing sequential, multi-frame optical correlations (correlating input data to reference data in the frequency domain to produce output information based on the correlation), the operation of the correlator may occasionally be interrupted, preferably under the control of the digital computer36for a few frames of adaptive alignment. The intervals between such adaptive alignment frames should be determined by the thermal and mechanical environment of the device. The alignment can typically be done quickly, requiring only a low clock cycle and resulting in the loss of only a few frames of the activity of the correlator. After the alignment process is performed, the correlator is switched back to its normal optical processing tasks until the next alignment interval. title: Optimal degaussing using an evolution program
abstract: An evolutionary program is used to calibrate a ship degaussing system with respect to one or more parameters relating to the ship's magnetic signature. Pursuant to the computer program, a mathematical vector lists electrical current values which correlate with the degaussing coils. A genetic algorithm is executed through a certain number of generational iterations in order to find a solution vector which will optimize the parameter(s). Every generational population has the same number of vectors. An initial population is randomly engendered, and successive populations are engendered through a biasedly random process wherein each vector has associated therewith a parenthood selection probability which is commensurate with its fitness. The offspring vectors are given birth to via crossover hybridization of parent vectors, and a small fraction of offspring vectors are randomly modified via mutation. The present invention is suitable for accomplishing optimization (e.g., minimization) of practically any parameter bearing relation to an entity's magnetic signature—i.e., not only of the magnetic signature itself but also of a variety of properties related thereto or derivative thereof. Depending on the inventive embodiment, a given genetic algorithmic program is capable of optimizing any number of diverse electromagnetic characteristics of any entity with respect to which a system of coils is being implemented.

title: System for matching stereo image in real time
abstract: A system for processing stereo matching of a video image sequence in a real-time mode. The system includes a signal converter for converting an image input from a first camera and a second camera into a digital signal; and an image matching clip for calculating a determined matching cost based on a pair of pixels in one scan line of the first and second digital image signals, tracing the decision value which determines the minimum matching cost, and outputting the decided value as an estimated disparity according to determined activation information; and a display for displaying the output from the image matching. According to the system, real-time stereo matching is enabled by parallel processing or video image sequences using an algorithm which is based on a new dynamic trellis based method and is optimal in the Bayesian sense.

title: Fingerprint verification system
abstract: A biometric verification system for controlling access is provided that does not rely on a non-biometric discriminator, such as a PIN or magnetic card, to convert a one-to-many verification task to a one-to-one verification task. The system enrolls authorized users by obtaining digitized fingerprint templates from them and storing them in a database. Video cameras and fingerprint sensors are provided for use in authenticating persons seeking access. Software compares a digital representation of a captured human facial image with stored facial images in a database of facial images, generating a match confidence therefrom and rank-ordering the database from highest to lowest match confidence. The software then compares captured human fingerprints with stored fingerprint templates associated with the rank-ordered database to verify the identity of the person and provide an output signal indicative of recognition.

title: Introduction support method and system, and introduction method and system
abstract: Introduction service is supported, in order to activate and facilitate community activities. A community management center1searches for offered-service information that matches at least partly with an application designated by a coordinator terminal2, and selects participants specified by detected offered-service information, as introduction candidates. Then, an introduction candidate list that describes private information, desired terms, and possessed value of ticket for each of the selected introduction candidates is displayed on a coordinator terminal2. When the coordinator terminal2selects a participant to be introduced to the applicant, out of the introduction candidates described in the introduction candidate list, then, the private information and the desired terms of selected participant is displayed on a participant terminal3of the applicant.

title: Method and system for providing intelligent network management
abstract: A network management system and method is disclosed for providing an intelligent decision support system for assisting human operators monitor, maintain, and diagnose and solve problems with a network. According to one embodiment, a system and method is provided that uses a partial order planner and a knowledge base to implement intelligent decision support using knowledge stored as plan and goal graphs, concept graphs, and/or scripts.

title: Method and system for estimating the accuracy of inference algorithms using the self-consistency methodology
abstract: The present invention provides a method for measuring the self-consistency of inference algorithms. The present invention provides a method for measuring the accuracy of an inference algorithm that does not require comparison to ground truth. Rather, the present invention pertains to a method for measuring the accuracy of an inference algorithm by comparing the outputs of the inference algorithm against each other. Essentially, the present invention looks at how well the algorithm applied to many of the different observations gives the same answer. In particular, the present invention provides a method that is not time and labor intensive and is cost effective.

title: Neural progenitor cell populations
abstract: This invention provides populations of neural progenitor cells, differentiated neurons, glial cells, and astrocytes. The populations are obtained by culturing stem cell populations (such as embryonic stem cells) in a cocktail of growth conditions that initiates differentiation, and establishes the neural progenitor population. The progenitors can be further differentiated in culture into a variety of different neural phenotypes, including dopaminergic neurons. The differentiated cell populations or the neural progenitors can be generated in large quantities for use in drug screening and the treatment of neurological disorders.

title: Feedback control of strip time to reduce post strip critical dimension variation in a transistor gate electrode
abstract: A method for decreasing variations in gate electrode widths is provided. The method includes providing a wafer having a gate electrode formed thereon and an anti-reflective coating layer formed over at least a portion of the gate electrode. The gate electrode has a width. The width of the gate electrode is measured. A strip rate for a strip tool adapted to remove the anti-reflective coating is determined. The measured width of the gate electrode is compared to a target gate electrode critical dimension to determine an overetch time based on the strip rate. The operating recipe of the strip tool is modified based on the overetch time. A processing line includes a first metrology tool, a strip tool, and a process controller. The first metrology tool is adapted to measure the width of a gate electrode formed on a wafer. The gate electrode has an anti-reflective coating layer formed over at least a portion of the gate electrode. The strip tool is adapted to remove the anti-reflective coating. The process controller is adapted to determine a strip rate for the strip tool, compare the width of the gate electrode to a target gate electrode critical dimension to determine an overetch time based on the strip rate, and modify the operating recipe of the strip tool layer based on the overetch time.

title: System and method for processing database queries
abstract: A system and method is provided wherein a user chooses from an allowed preselected domain of query element values, presenting a query comprising a plurality of selected query element values, which form the basis for indexing query results. A database lookup is done according to the user's selections and index values, as well as relevancy values of other members of the allowed preselected domain of query element values. In some embodiments the query results are assigned to arbitrary tags or numbers to prevent unauthorized competing search providers from appropriating the query results.

title: Methods for measuring therapy resistance
abstract: The present invention concerns methods for measuring drug resistance by correlating genotypic information with phenotypic profiles. In one embodiment, a method for interpreting genotypic information is described wherein a genetic code is generated from a patient sample, a list of mutations known or suspect to play a role in the development of resistance to one or more drugs is obtained from the generated genetic code, a genotype database is interrogated for previous samples with similar mutations relating to said one or more drugs, a phenotype for said sample is located in a phenotype database, the mean change in inhibition is determined based on all the examples located in said phenotype database, a distribution of sensitivities of one or more drugs suitable for treating a specific indication is determined.

title: Left-corner chart parsing
abstract: Different embodiments of the present invention provide improvements to left-corner chart parsing. The improvements include a specific order of filtering checks, transforming the grammar using bottom-up prefix merging, indexing productions first based on input symbols, grammar flattening, and annotating chart edges for the extraction of parses.

title: Computer-based 3D visual field test system and analysis
abstract: A method and apparatus for electronically performing a visual field test for a patient. A visual field test pattern is displayed to the patient on an electronic display device and the patient's responses to the visual field test pattern are recorded. A visual field representation is generated from the patient's responses. The visual field representation is then used as an input into a variety of diagnostic processes. In one embodiment of the invention, a series of visual test patterns of varying contrast are presented to a patient in order to construct a three-dimensional visual field representation wherein contrast sensitivity is plotted against a Z-axis.

title: Method and system for dynamic pricing
abstract: The method and system of the present invention enables Internet businesses to conduct real-time, online experiments on a sample of transactions to determine marketplace sensitivities. Analysis of the results of the experiments reveal optimal values of key market decision variables such as price, content of banner ads, promotion levels, quantity discount schemes, etc. The experiments may be automatically conducted on an on-going basis, or may be conducted on a periodic basis. The method and system of the present invention preferably allow users to modify the nature of the experiment and the propagation of optimal values. The method and system of the current invention can be used for a pure diagnostic purpose or to automate the setting of key market variables. The dynamic experimentation used by the inventive system reveals the relative stability (or instability) of the networked market within which the business operates. The translation of an optimal value for a key variable (for example, price) to the entire market can be done on a real-time basis.

title: System and method for grouping multiple VLANs into a single 802.11 IP multicast domain
abstract: A system and method for identifying and grouping multiple virtual local area networks into a single multicast domain is provided. The system and method may be configured to designate a virtual local area network within as a multicast virtual local area network to streamline the delivery of multicast messages via a network. A station may be configured with multiple group keys so that it can receive messages from multiple broadcast or multicast domains.

title: Method and system for object detection in digital images
abstract: An object detection system for detecting instances of an object in a digital image includes an image integrator and an object detector, which includes a classifier (classification function) and image scanner. The image integrator receives an input image and calculates an integral image representation of the input image. The image scanner scans the image in same sized subwindows. The object detector uses a cascade of homogenous classification functions or classifiers to classify the subwindows as to whether each subwindow is likely to contain an instance of the object. Each classifier evaluates one or more features of the object to determine the presence of such features in a subwindow that would indicate the likelihood of an instance of the object in the subwindow.

title: Computer method and apparatus for segmenting text streams
abstract: Computer method and apparatus for segmenting text streams is disclosed. Given is an input text stream formed of a series of words. A probability member provides working probabilities that a group of words is of a topic selected from a plurality of predetermined topics. The probability member accounts for relationships between words. A processing module receives the input text stream and using the probability member determines probability of certain words in the input text stream being of a same topic. As such, the processing module segments the input text stream into single topic groupings of words, where each grouping is of a respective single topic.

title: Backlash compensation using neural network
abstract: Methods and systems for backlash compensation. Restrictive assumptions on the backlash nonlinearity (e.g. the same slopes of the lines, etc.) are not required. The compensator scheme has dynamic inversion structure, with a neural network in the feedforward path that approximates the backlash inversion error plus filter dynamics needed for backstepping design. The neural network controller does not require preliminary off-line training. Neural network tuning is based on a modified Hebbian tuning law, which requires less computation than backpropagation. The backstepping controller uses a practical filtered derivative, unlike the usual differentiation required by earlier backstepping routines. Rigorous stability proofs are given using Lyapunov theory. Simulation results show that the proposed compensation scheme is an efficient way of improving the tracking performance of a vast array of nonlinear systems with backlash.

title: Vehicular component control methods based on blind spot monitoring
abstract: Method for controlling a vehicular system based on the presence of an object in an environment around a vehicle with one goals being to prevent collisions between the vehicle and any objects. Infrared light is emitted from the vehicle into a portion of the environment around the vehicle and received by a sensor on the vehicle. Distance between the vehicle and an object from which the infrared light is reflected is determined based on the emission of the infrared light and reception of the infrared light. The presence of and an identification of the object from which light is reflected is/are determined based at least in part on the received infrared light. The vehicular system is controlled or adjusted based on the determination of the presence of an object in the environment around the vehicle and the identification of the object and the distance between the object and the vehicle.

title: Simulating human intelligence in computers using natural language dialog
abstract: A method and apparatus for simulating human intelligence and natural language dialog capability is disclosed. The present invention contains a cognitive model of human intelligence (20), a mathematical model of information abstraction, synthetic dialog interaction (202), a method of language-independent computer learning through training (201), interaction and document reading (203) and a method of efficient computer implementation (200) of all preceding parts. The cognitive model (20) is the theoretical basis of the entire invention, describes the way humans learn and interact in general terms, provides a mathematical basis for natural language (40) learning and interaction and establishes a basis for detailed computer implementation of the theory.

title: Endoscope with guiding apparatus
abstract: An endoscope with guiding apparatus is described herein. A steerable endoscope is described having an elongate body with a manually or selectively steerable distal portion, an automatically controlled portion, a flexible and passively manipulated proximal portion, and an externally controlled and manipulatable tracking rod or guide. The tracking rod or guide is positioned within a guide channel within the endoscope and slides relative to the endoscope. When the guide is in a flexible state, it can conform to a curve or path defined by the steerable distal portion and the automatically controlled portion. The guide can then be selectively rigidized to assume that curve or path. Once set, the endoscope can be advanced over the rigidized guide in a monorail or “piggy-back” fashion so that the flexible proximal portion follows the curve held by the guide until the endoscope reaches a next point of curvature within a body lumen.

title: System, method and program for augmenting information retrieval in a client/server network using client-side searching
abstract: In a system, method and program for identifying information accessible over a client/server network, search results obtained by a search engine running on a server may be improved by utilizing computing resources on a client. Initial search results produced by the server search engine are further processed on the client machine, which may produce a more refined set of search results. The processing on the client machine may be done using a client-side search program. The usefulness of the search results to a user may therefore be improved without the need for additional server resources. Data associated with the additional search results produced by the processing on the client may be sent back to the server. The server may then update its search engine such that results for subsequent searches on the server may be improved. A system for implementing the improved searching may include a network server having a server-side search program and a network client having a browser and a client-side search program. Program instructions implementing methods of the improved searching using such a system may be included on a carrier medium, which may be a transmission medium or storage medium.

title: Commercial insurance scoring system and method
abstract: A quantitative system and method that employs data sources external to an insurance company to generate a statistical model that may be used to predict commercial insurance profitability. The system and method are able to predict individual commercial insurance policyholder profitability on a prospective basis regardless of the internal data and business practices of a particular insurance company.

title: Smart blocks
abstract: A child's construction set contains virtual intelligence, is interactive and smart, characteristics that may be exhibited to a player during player construction activity with the set and, thereafter, during continuing play and instills a sense of unpredictability to play. The set incorporates a programmed controller (17), a speaker (23), special (“smart”) play pieces or blocks (1,3,5,7, et cet.) and a base (15) on which to position the play pieces or blocks. Sensors (A1-C3), referred to as “hot spots”, are distributed at various positions about the base and are coupled to the controller, whereby the controller identifies special play pieces and the location of those play pieces when the respective play piece is installed at one of those positions. Some of the special play pieces may depict characters, some contain electrically operated devices, and some contain a player operated input device. The controller issues speech messages or other audible effects through the speaker to effect a virtual personality to the character play pieces; controls operation of electrically operated devices in special blocks, and detects and responds to player inputs from the player input blocks. Through wireless communication devices, the controller may acquire information from and supply speech messages to accessory blocks that are used off the base of the construction set.

title: Use of cyclic AMP and ascorbic acid to produce dopaminergic neurons from embryonic stem cells
abstract: This disclosure provides improved methods for obtaining populations of dopaminergic neurons from pluripotent stem cells. The process involves taking a population of neural precursor cells derived from a line of human embryonic stem cells, and culturing the cells in a medium that contains a neurotrophin, either cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) or a compound that elevates intracellular cAMP levels, and optionally an antioxidant such as ascorbic acid. Cell populations have been obtained that contain a high proportion of cells staining for tyrosine hydroxylase, which is a feature of dopaminergic neurons. The neural progenitors and terminally differentiated neurons of this invention can be generated in large quantities for use in drug screening and the treatment of clinically important neurological disorders, such as Parkinson's disease.

title: Systems, method and program product for pattern information processing
abstract: A method for processing information about a polygonal pattern in the context of pattern recognition in a computer environment, the method comprising the steps of:(a) taking the corners of the pattern in turn in order from a first of the corners through the last of the corners, forming a first ordered sequence M of values representing the respective scalar distances between each corner of the polygonal pattern and each other corner, the sequence including (i) the distances between said first of said corners and each other corner in turn and (ii) taking each other corner in turn, the distances between that other corner and each other corner starting with the said first corner, and (iii) including at appropriate positions in the sequence zero values to correspond to the distance between each corner and itself;(b) re-ordering the values of said first sequence M to form a second ordered sequence P1comprising a set of values p1which includes for each corner starting with said first corner, values in a series starting with and including the said zero value for that corner and including the other values for that corner in one direction through, the order in which they appear in said first sequence; and(c) converting said values in the second ordered sequence P1to respective equal-length character strings representative of the values.

title: Predicting values of a series of data
abstract: Communications data such as traffic levels in a communications network is analysed using techniques adapted from the study of chaos. Future values of a series of communications data are predicted and an attractor structure is determined from the communications data. This enables the communications processes to be monitored, controlled and analysed. Action can be taken to modify the communications process using the results from the prediction and attractor structure to reduce costs and improve performance and efficiency. These methods may also be used for product data from manufacturing processes. An algorithm bank is compiled containing prediction algorithms suitable for different types of data series, including those exhibiting deterministic behaviour and those exhibiting stochastic behaviour. Recent past values of a data series are taken and assessed or audited in order to determine which of the algorithms in the bank would provide the optimal prediction. The selected algorithm is then used to predict future values of the data series. The assessment or auditing process is carried out in real time and a prediction algorithm selected using a “smart switch” such that different algorithms are used for different stages in a given series as required. This enables good prediction of data series which change in nature over time to be obtained.

title: COMPOSITION FOR THE PREVENTION OF CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES
abstract: This invention relates to a method for the prevention of cardiovascular disease, a formulation for the prevention of cardiovascular disease, the use of specified active principals for the manufacture of such a formulation for use in the method and to a method of preparing said formulation. The formulation of the present invention is a combination of active principals for use in the prevention of cardiovascular disease, notably ischaemic heart disease (including heart attacks) and stroke among the general adult population.

title: Voice-interactive marketplace providing promotion and promotion tracking, loyalty reward and redemption, and other features
abstract: The invention provides a system, method, and business model for an information system and service having business self-promotion, promotion and promotion tracking, loyalty or frequent participant rewards and redemption, audio coupon, ratings, and other features. A business or organization in which consumers call into a service using ordinary telephone, PC, PDA, or other information appliance, and make requests in plain speech for information on goods and/or services, and the service provides responses to the request in plain speech in real-time. Provides operating model for a telephone-based audio-interfaced goods and services information and referral service having merchant self-promotion features, including database provider storing merchant information; an interface for inputting merchant information into the database and for retrieving and editing the information; and an interface for inputting voice commands and data and for receiving merchant information and processed information from the database in response to the input voice commands and data.

title: METHOD FOR THE DIAGNOSIS OF LIVER ILLNESS, USING BIOCHEMICAL CHARACTERISTICS
abstract: The present invention is drawn to a new diagnosis method for detecting the extend of a inflammatory, fibrotic or cancerous disease in a patient, in particular liver fibrosis, in particular in a patient infected with hepatitis C virus, by using the serum concentration of easily detectable biological markers. The invention is also drawn to diagnosis kits for the implementation of the method.

title: Recognition system using lexical trees
abstract: The dynamic programming technique employs a lexical tree that is encoded in computer memory as a flat representation in which the nodes of each generation occupy contiguous memory locations. The traversal algorithm employs a set of traversal rules whereby nodes of a given generation are processed before the parent nodes of that generation. The deepest child generation is processed first and traversal among nodes of each generation proceeds in the same topological direction.

title: Optical sensor for the detection of several analytes
abstract: The The present invention relates to devices and methods for simultaneously analyzing multiple analytes in fluids and in particular, to devices and methods for simultaneous Determine the concentration of multiple analytes in an unknown Fluid sample using an optical interrogation. The Analytical chemistry is and has been instrumental in making it worldwide Billions of people a healthier and to allow a more pleasant life. Some examples of instruments that can detect multiple analytes simultaneously are AVL Opti CCA, Chiron Centaur, Instrumentation Laboratory GEM 201, I-STAT Portable Analyzer, etc. AVL Opti CCA is a portable analyzer that provides the measurement of pH, total hemoglobin, Oxygen saturation, blood gas and electrolyte parameters. The analyzer uses an Opti-CCA cassette system, which is a disposable cassette system incorporating optical sensing technology. The cassette contains optical fluorescence sensors, one each for pH, PCO2, PO2, Na+, K+, iCa++(ionic calcium) and Cl-. The analytes SO2and tHb (total hemoglobin) are measured using optical absorbance. Also Diameterics' IRMA is a portable analyzer that measures pH, PCO2, PO2, Na+, K+, iCa++, Cl-, Hct (hematocrit) and glucose. Diameterics' IRMA has disposable cartridges designed to provide various combinations of these parameters using an electrochemical sensor for each parameter. The glucose cartridge is a standalone cartridge utilizing optical reflectance technology. The I-STAT device also uses cartridges based on electrochemical sensors, one for each parameter. For different combinations of the parameters pH, PCO2,PO2,Na+,K+,iCa++,Cl-,Hct, glucose, blood urea nitrogen (BUN = blond urea nitrogen) include and creatinine, several different cartridges are available. It should be noted that although a large number of parameters can be measured using these analyzers, none of these analyzers can be used to analyze all parameters using a single cartridge. In addition, analyzers often use a combination of both optical and electrochemical sensing technologies. Also if a simultaneous analysis of a plurality of analytes already possible is, the analytical tools are often complex. The sensors are designed around for the analyte they target to be specific and none other analyte that may be present in the sample. A disadvantage of such processes is that they are highly specific Sensor must be designed. A design of such a high specificity is costly and time consuming and not always convenient. Although it would seem that an instrument based on this concept should be simple and inexpensive, the sensors themselves are highly nonselective. Wolfbeis et al. For example, "Non-Crosslinked Organosilicon Matrix for Luminescent Quenching based Fiber Optic Oxygen Sensors" SPIE Proceedings, Vol. 1886, (1993), by Mauze et al., Shows that the luminophore of these sensors is also sensitive to oxygen, such as those described by Wolfbeis et al Therefore, they are not applicable per se to measurements in a changing oxygen environment. Another type of legacy sensing device uses arrays of sensors that are highly nonspecific to the volatile analytes in the sample. Such devices are z. Such arrays consist of sensors that have physical, optical or electrical properties such. B. density, refractive angles or electrical resistance, which change in relation to the concentrations of the species that penetrate to the sensing element of the sensors change. The changes in such properties are measured and the data are analyzed using pattern recognition methods to determine the concentration of each species. Such sensors have a limited dynamic range dictated by the characteristics of the detection region. In addition, these acquisition arrays can only be used to analyze volatile species. These sensors respond to any species that penetrates the detection region. Calibration models or sets of exercises must be designed to encompass all such species that might be present in the sample. Thus, they are susceptible to interference when encountering a special species. a Designing a sensor that responds to just one analyte, is a very difficult task. Many sensors with which experiments had been abandoned since interference could not be removed by one or more other analytes. Often it is just one species that interferes with the measurement. In such cases Attempts have been made to provide a sensor specifically for the interfering Species without interference from others, mathematical for interference is correct to design. However, such an additional sensor requires a new method for interrogating the sensor. This increases the complexity of the instrument. This challenge is particularly daunting if a large number must be measured by analytes and many species with each other interfere. Often it is not possible to do a highly specific Sensor for to produce an interfering species. Using pattern recognition methods, the analytes can be characterized in a multi-analyte fluid. An example of fluids that could be analyzed using the devices and methods of this invention is blood. For example, if there are N analytes, the concentration and presence of the N analytes can be determined by M sensors SENSOR1, SENSOR2, SENSOR3, SENSOR4, ..., SENSORM(where N ≤ M), each of which is in the same a chemical for specifically interacting with a different analyte. In one implementation of the principles set forth above, each of the sensor arrays includes one or more of the following elements: 1) a main matrix component, such as a master matrix component; A hydrophilic or hydrophobic polymer with or without one or more modifiers. A modifier may be a plasticizer, a buffer solution, a filler, or any such species that enhances the functionality of the sensing elements. For example, a plasticizer may be included in a polymer matrix to enhance mobility of the analyte or a complex thereof into or within the matrix, and a filler may be included to modify the physical property such that the matrix is the desired one having physical strength and dimensional stability. Buffers may be added to control the pH. 2) A recognition element that alters its chemical state or conformational state with high specificity in response to the analyte of interest. Such a recognition element may be an analyte-specific chemical that has a more specific chemical recognition interaction with an analyte of interest than with other analytes suspected of being contained in an unknown sample to be analyzed. The recognition element will be described in more detail below. An example of such an analyte-specific chemical is an ionophore, such as an ionophore. B. valinomycin to which a potassium ion, K+, can bind. 3) A chemical element that changes its chemical state depending on the number of recognition events, the altered state itself being an optically absorbing species. An illustrative example of such a chemical element is a dye or a chemical indicator, such as. B. Bromothymolblau, which changes its color with the pH. 4) A chemical element which fluoresces in proportion to the amount of excitation radiation supplied thereto, the frequency characteristics of the emitted fluorescence radiation being at least partially matched to the optical absorption characteristics of the altered state of the element in 3). Each of the sensors formed in this manner responds to (ie, targets) a main analyte and may have interference from one or more of the other sample parameters. The selection of elements to be included in a sensor is made such that the sensor based on a given composition has a response that is preferably not proportional to a response of any other sensor to a particular environmental parameter change, e.g. B. is a change in the oxygen concentration is. In other words, the response of the sensor to a particular environmental change has a component that is preferably orthogonal to the response of other sensors (having other combinations of elements in the sensor array) to the same environmental change. Thus, a sufficiently large number of these combinations can be selected to produce an assembly that allows complete and accurate analysis of the desired analytes in the sample. Such ionophores are lipophilic inclusion compounds, which usually have a ring structure. In such a compound, the ring contains several slightly electronegative atoms such. B. oxygen. The size of the ring and the total number of oxygen atoms determine the relative preference (selectivity) of the ionophore for cations of different sizes and charged states. Another ionophore class undergoes conformational changes following selective cation binding. Thus, a double ring ethers-based ionophore, referred to as BME-44, forms a double-shelled inclusion for a captured potassium ion. BME-44 has two ring ethers connected by a three carbon chain. Is a potassium ion present. If a potassium ion is present, the two crown ethers fold over to form the double shell. However, the present invention is also applicable regardless of the scientific theory regarding ionophores. These Ionophores are lipophilic and are in a hydrophobic polymer such as As polyvinyl chloride (PVC) together with a large amount a plasticizer masked. The ionophores extract the selective Ion from the watery Solution, which is in contact with the polymer surface. The excess of charge built up in the polymer can be used to form another, less desirable cation, such as a cation. B. H+ tosplit off from the polymer phase. Alternatively, a charged bilayer is formed on the surface of the polymer. The number of cleaved cations or the potential gradient on the surface is proportional to the concentration of the cation in the aqueous solution. Similar ionophores are also for some anions such. Ru (Didipy). 3Figure 4 is an absorbance and luminescence graph of the elements in such a system (as described by Wolfbeis et al. above) showing how it can be used to detect the presence and amount of potassium ions. In3is a curve V1, the absorbance of a reactive indicator dye N-9 under alkaline conditions of about pH 9 (ie, in an alkaline solution). A curve V2 is the absorbance of dye N-9 under acidic conditions of about pH 4. These two curves show that the absorbance peak moves with the changing of the pH along the frequency axis (in other words, the wavelength axis). A curve V3 is the absorbance of the fluorophore Ru complex (ie Ru (Didipy)). A curve V4 is the fluorescence emission of the Ru complex. According to the present invention, by exploiting the fact that pH changes the absorbance wavelength of the indicator dye, the fluorescence intensity of the fluorophore in a solution can be used to detect the pH change. If z. For example, when the fluorophore is excited by a light of about 470 nm, the fluorophore emits fluorescence in a region peaking at about 630 nm. This fluorescent peak overlaps with the absorbance peak of N-9 at pH 9. Thus, a portion of the fluorescent light is absorbed by the dye. When K+ is taken upby the ionophore valinomycin, the charge balance requires that the weak acid (valinomycin) cleave an H+resulting in a decrease in pH. As the pH drops, the absorbance peak of dye N-9 moves toward shorter wavelengths and therefore absorbs less of the fluorescence of the Ru complex. Further, the N-9 absorbance peak may approach close enough to the absorbance peak of the fluorophore Ru complex to compete with the fluorophore for the excitation light from a light source, further reducing the fluorescence of the Ru complex. Thus, the fluorescence emission of the Ru complex can be detected to indicate the pH change in the solution. Several different indicators can be used in different sensors to detect the same analyte. Obviously, different indicator dyes have different absorbance characteristics, and different fluorophores have different excitation and fluorescence characteristics. By judicious selection of indicator dyes and fluorophores, different sensors can be made to provide different fluorescence emissions in the same pH range or in different pH ranges. As mentioned above, an analyte can be analyzed using two or more different chemistry methods. For example, a glucose sensor may be based on the enzymatic action of glucose oxidase to convert glucose to gluconic acid, which is a weak acid and would result in a change in pH. Moreover, conversion of glucose to gluconic acid consumes O2and the changes in oxygen content in a sample can be measured to derive the concentration of glucose in the sample. Another example is urea, which can be converted to CO2and NH3by the enzymatic action of urease. CO2dissolves in a bicarbonate solution and changes its pH, which can be measured by a pH sensor. The formed NH3is consumed by nitrification bacteria that consume O2. Thus, the urea concentration can be determined by a sensor with nitrification bacteria and a pH detection capability. Different matrices (eg, membranes) may be used for different gases to provide different solubilities of the gases in the matrices. To detect ions via pH measurement by the method of using an ion-specific ionophore and an indicator dye, sensors can be made using several different pH-sensitive indicator dyes. These indicator dyes are selected to have different pK values and thus a different sensitivity to pH changes. In order to measure a plurality of analytes simultaneously, this invention takes advantage of the fact that the degree of interference is different for different sensors, depending on the chemical composition selected for the sensor. Each of the sensors has varying amounts of interference from the analyte species in the sample. Thus, using a large number of sensors and using correlation techniques, the composition of the sample relative to the species of analyte can be determined. Such correlation methods have been used in other fields of research and we have recognized that they adopt analyte analysis in the present invention  can be. The foregoing description has shown that the analytes of interest can all be measured using either a pH sensor or an oxygen sensor or both. The Stern-Volmer equations (S23 and S26) show that the sensor signal τ or IF islinearly dependent on the concentration of the extinguisher [Q]. In the case of the oxygen sensor, the quencher is the analyte. In the case of the pH sensor and other sensors measuring an analyte concentration based on titration of a pH-sensitive indicator (the second element), the sensor signal is a characteristic S-shaped titration curve (see8th, Wolfbeis et al., Above). The sensitivity of these sensors is greatest when the measured sensor signal (τ or IF) is on the quasi-linear central portion of the indicator titration curve. One method of achieving this is to incorporate a weak acid or base (an example is sodium bicarbonate) into the sensor membrane (element (1)) to adjust the pH of the sensor in the linear region. Such a component of the element (1) effectively shifts the titration curve to allow the sensor to be effective in the linear region for the selected indicator. In the sensor arrays of this invention, a number of sensors may be used that differ only in the pK value of the indicator or (including) the type and concentration of the acid / base component that shifts the titration curve. This ensures that for a given dynamic range of analyte concentrations, a number of sensors are effective in the linear response range. Therefore, only the linear sensors can be selected from an array to perform the calibration and detection mathematical operations. One another method well known in the art of analysis is known as the "standard addition method." In this The method will be an appropriate amount of the analytes of interest added to the concentrations of the analytes in the linear To move area. Thus could varying amounts of the analytes in the sensor arrays of this invention be incorporated into element (1) so that the area over which the analyte concentration distributes when a sample is mixed is, is linear. Thus, the methods of this invention can be used to linearize the response of the sensors. Therefore, calibration and modeling of the sensor arrays can be represented by a linear matrix equation:S = MC Eq. 3,where S is a column vector representing the signals obtained from the n sensors in the array. M is an n × m matrix representing the parameters that correlate the sensor signals with the concentrations of the analytes (including interferents). Finally, C is an m × 1 matrix containing the concentrations of the analytes in the sample. In Matrix M have only the columns that the interfering Analytes correspond to non-zero values. Thus, if only the pH and oxygen concentrations produce a response from the sensors, only two columns of the matrix M have nonzero values. When a size Number of analytes in a large number of sensors one Interference, the matrix is more complex. In any case, such an equation by chemometric methods such. B. PLS be solved. In PLS, the unknown concentration, Cun, of an analyte can be determined from the signal, Sun, which is obtained from the sample by using the following equation:Cun= GSandEq. 4,where G is estimated from the columns of a matrix R of sensor signals in response to a series of calibration samples of concentrations C. The matrix G is then estimated by:G = CR+Eq.5,where R+ isthe pseudoinverse of R. As previously mentioned, the number of analytes to be analyzed may be less than the number of analytes (including interferents) that contribute to the sensor signals. In such cases, it may not be necessary to know the concentrations of the interferents in the calibration samples to produce G. If all concentrations in C are known, a multicomponent analysis can be used to determine the calibration. If only the values of some of the rows of C are known, PLS can be used for calibration. Mathematically, several methods for determining the pseudoinverse of R can be used by those skilled in the art. The most reliable and comprehensive method is based on singular value decomposition (SVD). The application of this method to determine R+and thus G is well known in the literature (eg, Linear Algebra and its Applications, Gilbert Strang, Chapter 9, Academic Press, New York).
