title: Neural network system for estimating conditions on submerged surfaces of seawater vessels
abstract: An algorithm method of predicting estimated sea energy, wave directions and other seastate data with respect to submerged sea-going vessels, based on inputs derived from signal processed measurements of keel depth, pitch, roll and forward speed applied to three neural networks for heading detection and to a fourth neural network for seastate estimations.

title: Video game with bonusing or wild feature
abstract: A method of playing a wagering game comprises placing a wager in a reel-type video wagering game, and playing a first game segment in the reel-type video wagering game in which symbols are randomly displayed to the player. At least some displayed symbols may be non-monetary credit symbols, and after playing the first game segment, the player may accumulate the non-monetary credit symbols. Upon the occurrence of a special feature or event, a monetary value is randomly assigned to the non-monetary credit symbols, and a payout is resolved, based at least in part on the monetary value assigned to the non-monetary credit symbols. The method may have the player accumulate non-monetary credits in a first game segment, and the random assignment of a monetary value or values to the non-monetary credits occurs in a second game segment.

title: PROCEDURE AND DEVICE FOR TRAFFIC PREDICTION THROUGH A NEURONAL NETWORK.
abstract: Prediction procedure, in successive prediction windows (Tp), of a traffic (5) in a telecommunications network, according to which: a) information (Uô, I) that characterizes the traffic passed in the first ones is produced permanently respective observation windows (T1);

title: System for recognizing the same vehicle at different times and places
abstract: In a vehicle time-of-entry and time-of-exit system, the passing of a vehicle through an entrance generates a “trigger-t0” signal. An entrance video camera provides realtime images of entering vehicles. The trigger-t0signal causes one video frame of the image of vehicle to be stored or “frame-grabbed” in an entrance subsystem. A time-of-entry clock-time signal is used to time-stamp the image which is then forwarded on a connection to a matcher. The passing of a vehicle through an exit generates a “trigger-t1” signal. An exit video camera116provides realtime images of exiting vehicles. The trigger-t1signal causes one video frame of the image of vehicle to be stored or “frame-grabbed” in an exit subsystem. A clock-time signal is used to time-stamp the image which is then forwarded on a connection to the matcher. A output automatically provides a length-of-stay for each exiting vehicle according to its time-of-entry. The matcher uses the unique characteristics in the images of the vehicles to declare a match. While a license plate number is unique, reading any or all of a license plate is not necessary for the extraction of visual signatures related to particular cars. For example, in the limited variety of cars that would patronize a particular parking lot, the color, trim, style, tires, wheelcovers, collision damage, etc., of each vehicle can be used in combination to distinguish individual ones.

title: Dialogue processing system and method
abstract: An object of the present invention is to realize a natural dialogue with a system having a simple configuration. The dialogue processing system of the present invention to perform a dialogue with a user, comprises: a plurality of slots (slot11), wherein each of the slots is a storage area storing a preset information item (for example, boarding date, departure point, destination, or flight name) that are required to achieve the purpose of the dialogue with the user (for example, an airline ticket reservation); an analyzer (the speech details analyzer19) for extracting information corresponding to the information items from information (for example, free sentence entered in natural language) entered by the user in the dialogue and for storing the extracted information in the slot for that information item; and a response processor (the dialogue processor21) for outputting response information (a sentence prompting the input of insufficient information) to the user in accordance with information storage state of the slots.

title: Embedded system for diagnostics and prognostics of conduits
abstract: An apparatus providing a means for assessment of the integrity of insulated conduits, harnesses, cables, pipelines and other interconnection systems constructed with integral sensitized media, discrete sensors, and electronics providing a means for transforming sensed data into information and a means for communicating information for the purpose of understanding the location, degree and risk of damage and deterioration, and the probable causes thereof.

title: ARRANGEMENT FOR GENERATING ELEMENT SEQUENCES
abstract: The The present invention relates to an apparatus for generating Sequences of elements and is particularly, but not exclusively, suitable to generate sequences of elements, such as numbers or task names. Machine Learning Systems among other things, as a mechanism for learning information applied, which can then be applied to efficiently different Automate and control processes. In particular, neural Network systems see a means of extrapolating from learned Information before, to find a solution for problems to deliver that inherent unsolvable are through rule-based systems. Neural networks have one broad applicability in areas such as a finance organization, they provide, for example, capital forecasts, economic forecasts, bond rate forecasts and predictions for Mergers (Trippi, R. and E. Turban, (eds), Neural Networks in Finance and Investing, Irwin / Probus Publishing, 1993). Other uses for machine learning techniques include a data classification that can be applied around fault detection systems (e.g., for lines) or an automatic rating system (e.g., for Goods like apples) to design. Other uses include robotic systems that described as complex dynamic systems with many freedoms can be and operational are to perform series of movements, actions or procedures. In In the latter application, control of parameters can be learned and be applied to appropriate planning of actions too to reach.  Neural network systems used to learn sequences to generate scheduling and scheduling systems, or user tasks, take a process as a TSSG (Temporal Sequence Storage and Generation) into the system to generate a set of tasks. TSSG is based on observations of sequence retention by biological systems. There is a particular class of neural networks that is ideally suited for modeling TSSG since it can be trained using inductive learning algorithms. Current neural networks achieving TSSG include time delay networksiwhich implement hooks embedding theorem and various recurrent models such as spin-glassii; Networks with context neuronsiii; theElmannetworkiVand extensions thereofv; and the approach of "crumbling history"vi. However, the spin glass is limited to the reproduction of short sequences, the Elman network uses an associative chain to generate sequences which is computationally expensive, and the approach of " fragile history "can not plan successfully using learned sequences. In all of these cases, the ability of neural networks to successfully integrate into systems that perform complex planning tasks, such as pattern management, is limited. The journal publication "Temporal Associative Memory with Finite Internal States," Chengke Sheng and Yu-Cheng Liu, IEEE, New York, June 27, 1994, pp. 1109-1114 discloses an FSN (Finite State Network) which provides a temporary input pattern with a The FSN has three layers: an input layer, an output layer and a state layer, the layers being arranged such that for each state (Si) there is a corresponding element (Li) of the temporary input pattern and an element (Di). Essentially, a trained FSN can be represented as a tree, with each layer representing a different state (Si) and another element in the temporary pattern, such that the number of layers in the tree depends on The number of elements in the input pattern is The paper describes a specific example in which the FSN appears  String trained (input: OOD, output: OPQ) The trained FSN has a tree with three layers, where at least one of the paths in it follows [input / output] O / O; O / P; D / Q, so An output element is generated for each element of the temporary input sequence Once the FSN has traced a path through the tree, the outputs are grouped together to produce the output string OPQ. According to one In the first aspect of the invention, a "neural network" device is provided which that in claim 1 of the appended Set of claims having defined features. Preferably the identification means (i) comprises a plurality of classification units on, wherein each classification unit has a plurality of first classification node; a plurality of second classification nodes; and a variety of classification compounds. Each of the classification links connects one of the first classification nodes to one of the second classification node and has an associated classification weight. Each of the classification units is operable, one or more sequence (s) learning from elements by modifying the classification weights on the classification compounds. Preferably includes the sequence generator for generating sequences of elements (ii) one or more task units, each task unit has an upper and a lower neural network, which in a hierarchical relation and with each other Task units by means of intermediate sequence generator-weighted Connections are connected. According to one Another aspect of the present invention provides a method for training a device to a predetermined second or to produce a plurality having the features set forth in the claim 10 of the attached Set of claims To be defined. Further Aspects, features and advantages of the device for generating Sequences of elements are now exemplified as one embodiment of the present invention and with reference to the following Drawings are described, wherein: 1Figure 3 is a schematic block diagram of the hardware of a computer system configured to run a sequence generator of the present invention; 2Figure 3 is a schematic diagram showing the sequence generator interacting with a plurality of intelligent agents according to the present invention; 3Figure 3 is a schematic representation of the apparatus for generating sequences of elements according to one embodiment of the present invention; 4is a schematic representation of a recurrent neural network called the ACTION network for use in the device of3is known; 5is a schematic representation of a task unit comprising an upper and a lower ACTION network of4which are arranged in a hierarchical relation; 6a schematic representation of two task units of5is, each one upper and three lower ACTION networks of4which are arranged in a hierarchical relation; 7a schematic representation of two task units of5which are interconnected via a variable weighting connection; 8ais a schematic representation of identification means, which is part of the device of3turn off; 8bis a schematic representation of layers of a Kohonen SOM (Self-Organizing Map) unit, which is a part of the in8amake out the identification means shown; 8cis a directory of permutations of elements that has an input training set to the SOM of8bweight; 9FIG. 3 is a schematic block diagram illustrating training steps for use in the device of FIG3shows; 10FIG. 3 is a schematic block diagram illustrating operations for the device of FIG3shows. In the following description, the terms "layer", "node", "activity", "weighting", "inhibiting weighting", "stimulating weighting" and "weighting initialization" are used and defined as follows:a "layer": a data store, such as an array or a matrix of elements, the elements being the nodes described below;a "node": an array element that receives inputs from and delivers outputs to other array elements in the same layer or elements in other layers;"Activity": values in the array elements that are calculated from input functions of and output functions to connected layers;"Weight": a multiplier applied to the input and output functions that controls the amount of activity that is input to or output from each node;"Inhibiting weighting": a multiplier with a value less than 0;"Stimulating weighting": a multiplier with a value greater than 0;"Weighting initialization": the sequences generated by the present invention are controlled by the configuration of the layers, the functions between connected layers and the weights The means for generating a sequence of elements comprises a calculation process and the various parameters in the control equations require an appropriate initialization Thus, weighting initialization relates to the initial configuration of the weights."Task": a category of work, such as email, report, meeting, etc .;"Subtask": Components that have a task can be a subtask for a task of the email: open email, read email, reply to email, archive email, etc. General overview of operating layer With reference to1For example, one environment for carrying out the present invention is a general, conventional computer system100on, comprising: a conventional keyboard101; a display screen103like a CRT or plasma screen; a mouse105; a processor107such as a PentiumTMprocessor; a random access memory (RAM)109; a hard disk111; an audio input113like a microphone to capture the utterance of the user; and input / output interfaces115to connect the workstation to a local area network (LAN), wide area networks (WAN) and / or the Internet to facilitate data exchange, including e-mail messaging, with remote users associated with such Networks are connected. the interface115also allows a simple telephone service (POTS) control and the in1shown components are connected to each other via a common bus117connected. In addition to the in1shown single system configuration, multiple computer systems (not shown) via a local network via the input / output interface115be connected to each other. With reference also to2can a device201for generating sequences of elements to be executed by a computer system, generally referred to as a sequence generator, on the hard disk111are stored for processing by the processor107, In the embodiment described here, the sequence generator201part of an IA (intelligent assistant) system219which allows users to dedicate their time to very complex tasks while the system219Some decisions on behalf of the user or user are based on previous observations by the visitor or on stored user preferences. This is done by generating a sequence of items that are tasks that are performed by the IA system219for the user to execute. Typical tasks to be performed by the system include time, information and communication management. If the computer system has multiple computer workstations, multiple IA systems can219be active and communicate with each other. As in2shown, such an IA system219in addition a set of autonomous systems205.207.209.211.213.215.217commonly referred to as agents specialized in various tasks, such as appointment management, telephone call filtering and email prioritization, web search, telephone directory inquiry, multimodal interface, and communication flow management. Each agent has its own interface and interacts with the user in its own particular way, and the agents communicate with each other by sending messages. These agents assign re  active, collaborative, advisory and proactive agents that respond to events in the user's environment (such as email and phone calls) by initiating interactions with the user. The sequence generator201can with the appointment wizard205which can be the tasks of a user for a day, and create a sequence order for the tasks based on the knowledge of the user's preferred work patterns and what tasks the user has recently completed. This information can be considered a user profile203be available and may additionally include information concerning preferences as a function of the time of day and availability of the user with inputs from the agents that own the IA system219turn off. The sequence generator201can if he is in the intelligent assistant (IA) system219is integrated, also and / or alternatively used to organize inter-agent tasks, such that it dynamically directs a preferred order of agent tasks based on learned agent capabilities201, Thus, the elements generated by the sequence generator201ordered sequentially, include work items and subtasks for a range of entities, such as a user, part of a facility, or a business. In the following description, work tasks and subtasks of a user are described as examples of elements having sequences generated by embodiments of the present invention. A sequence generator201In accordance with one embodiment of the present invention, infrastructure management provides for tasks to be performed by an entity based on a learned context-based task order. In the context of the present invention, context-based means taking into account the tasks that have been performed before the tasks that make up the current schedule, as well as considering current intermediate task settings. If the tasks are machine-processable events, such as kernel events, or inter-agent transmission of information, the order in which a series of tasks, including, for example, system calls, is to be processed, is likely to depend on which Tasks have been completed previously. If the tasks are user-based, the selection of the tasks to be performed next is similarly likely, at least in part, to be determined by what tasks were previously performed. In this latter scenario, an embodiment of the present invention contemplates, among other things, the context of the user after completing the previous tasks. The sequence generator thus receives as input the previously completed tasks and issues a sequence of tasks in a preferred order that best suits the current context of the user. This output is preferably realized by a neural network system trained on previously observed context-based behavior patterns, as described below. Exemplary embodiment: Sequence generator for generating context-based sequences of elements Overview of the sequence generator201 As in3shown has the sequence generator201for generating context-based sequences of elements two parts, one identifying part303and a neural network part301, The sequence generator201can receive as input tasks that a user has already completed. The identifying part303of the sequence generator201compares these typed tasks with a known set of tasks. Then it gives a value representative of a best match to this known set of tasks (or a default if no best match can be found) to the neural network part301off and the neural network301generates a subsequent task sequence based on the value of "best match" it receives. As described below, the identifying part303a classifier, such as an SOM (Self-Organizing Map) system304, have and connecting means305a.305b, which are described below, may be the value that is attached to the SOM system304is output with the neural network part301connect. For example, by using such a system, the user may perform some tasks that the appointment assistant205supervised. The appointment assistant205Gives this set of tasks to the SOM system304which operates by accessing stored sequences of previously-observed tasks to find a best match between the stored sequences of tasks and the received task's input sequence. The SOM system304identifies this best match by means of an output signal and the output signal is sent to the neural network system301transfer. Once the neural network301an input signal from the SOM system304has received the neural network301a sequence of tasks, as described in detail below. As in3is described by the SOM system304a plurality of individual self-organizing imaging units304a.304beach of which has access to (different) stored sequences. The best match between the received sequence and stored sequences is thus identified by one of the self-organizing mapping units304a.304band the above-described output signal is thus a signal coming from the unit which has identified the best match. This output then becomes with each of the task units306connected, what, as in3as a unit304ais shown, about further connections305a.305bhappens. The sequence generator201provides increased functionality over the neural network system301alone, which only reproduces sequences that it has learned in isolation, ie for an input of, for example, 1 gives the neural network system301a pre-learned sequence of numbers. In contrast, the sequence generator replaces201effectively, the "1" input with an input representative of what was previously done, such as by an output from the SOM system304intended. Description of the identification means303 The identification means303has means for storing sequences of elements together with information used to perform a classification of the sequences. The identification means303can be provided by a variety of SOM (Self-Organizing Map) units304a.304b; a self-organizing map is known to those skilled in the art as a classifier. A SOM is an unattended learning neural network that is modular (in the sense that each SOM is independent and trained, requires no retraining), and is suitable for applications that do not require re-generation of sequences (such as the Case in the present invention). Further details of the SOM can be found, for example, in Fausett, L. (1994), Fundamentals of Neural Networks: Architectures, Algorithms, and Applications, Englewood Cliffs, NJ: Prentice Hall, ISBN-0-13-334186-0. The structure of a SOM includes an input layer801and an output layer803schematically in the8bbe shown, each layer nodes805having. Each node of the input layer801is configured to receive an input (represented by an input vector) and each input node is typically fully connected to each node on the output layer (shown only for one input node). There is also a weight associated with each connection from the input layer to the output layer. The input layer801may have any number of input nodes, but in general the number of input nodes should be greater than the dimension size of the output layer grid space (ie, if the output layer is 3x3, the dimension size is 3). As soon as trained is a SOM operational, receive an input and determine which node on the Output layer (best) corresponds to this input. Thus classified an SOM input by identifying a "winning" node on the Output layer. MODIFICATIONS AND ADDITIONAL DETAILS: As is well known in the art, a critical issue in the development of a neural network is generalization: how well does the network make predictions for cases that are not in the training set? Neural networks, like other flexible non-linear estimation techniques, such as kernel regression and smoothed splines, may suffer from either under-fitting or over-fitting. The number and choice of training data used to train the neural network is critical to the following performance: in simple terms, the training data is used to provide an empirical solution (the system "learns" this empirical solution), from which a solution for all data can be extrapolated, so the selection of input data used for training should lead to a representative solution, avoiding the problems of over-fitting, under-fitting, and reducing noise, as described above , the identification means303provided by means other than a plurality of SOM units, and when provided by another arrangement of a neural network, these alternative means require similar attention to training data. In general, a SOM unit attempts to find clusters such that two clusters that are close together in the output layer803, Vectors near each other in the input space, but this requires "a priori" knowledge about relationships between inputs (nodes) having the input layer In the present invention, it may be the case that all inputs are independent of each other, or that there is insufficient information available about their relationships, in which case an alternative, but more restrictive, form of means of identification may exist303provided by certain nodes that store information about just completed tasks. With such an arrangement, the sequences generated for inputs are less useful than when a SOM system is used, since the identification means can only provide guaranteed solutions that correspond to the particular node (ie, for input data for which the identifier was explicitly trained). There are a number of neural networks that achieve temporal sequence storage and generation. Neural time delay networks (Waibel, 1989; Waibel et al., 1989) implement Hook's embedding theorem, which states that measurements of a time series generated by an underlying dynamic system can always allow underlying dynamics to be reconstructed using an embedding vector of a delayed set of elements of the measured series. Recurrent models include: the Hopfield spin-glass approach (Hopfield, 1982); Networks with context neurons (Jordan, 198 ?, Elman 198?) And extensions of the Elman network (Wang & Arbib, 1990; 1996); the approach of "crumbling history" (Reiss & Taylor, 1991, Taylor & Reiss, 1992) We do not use the above models in our system The Hopfield model has problems with the length of the sequence being generated The Elman mesh approach uses associative chaining to create sequences, resulting in multiple representations for the same outputs, which is computationally expensive The "brittle history" approach encounters problems due to its method of sequence generation during design , He uses the last edition of the model as the next input,  during a concurrent process between different modules interrupting the output (ie, generating the incorrect output), creates competition between different sequences than originally intended. We require that a system learns long sequences in a way that is computationally less extensive than Elman meshes, and that the sequence generation is done in an "internal" manner as soon as sequence generation is started, thus turning the frontal lobe of Primates too. The ACTION network 2.1. architecture As mentioned above, is the first stage of building the system to develop a network that is capable to the temporary Sequence storage and generation of work actions. The one used for it Structure is the ACTION network (Taylor, 1995, Taylor & Alavi, 1996), a recurrent neural network. This is a schematic Version of the cortical and subcortical structures of the frontal lobes, being referred to as the basal ganglia-thalamocortical circuit becomes. The frontal lobes are important for a well-functioning memory entertainment and there are a number of separate circuits (Alexander, DeLong & Knit, 1986). The motor circuit is important for generating temporary sequences of motor actions from memory (Tanji & Shima, 1994; Halsband et al, 1994). Various versions of the ACTION NETWORK have been used to perform a variety of tasks, from psychologically delayed response tasks (Monchi & Taylor, 1995, 1997, 1998) to sequences of motor actions with delays (Taylor, 1998, Taylor & Taylor, 1998). The1shows the front areas modeled for the ACTION network version used here. The ACTION network has two cortical areas, SMA (supplemental motor cortex) and PMC (pre-motor cortex), basal ganglia, thalamus (THL) and STN (sub-thalamus nucleus). The basal ganglia consists of two layers, STR (striatum) and globus pallidus, each of which is modeled as its internal and external segments GPi and GPe. Neurophysiological and psychological studies have shown that SMA is responsible for movements from memory, whereas PMC generates movements from a visual instruction (Tanji & Shima, 1994, Halsband et al, 1994, Passingham 1987, 1993) and both are required to produce a visual statement learn new sequence (Passingham 1987, 1993). The modeled neurons have a medium rate of fire, with all but the ON and OFF neurons leaky integrators. This model can sustain an activity over a long period of time because of the many control loops that exist in its structure. Most of the subcortical structure provides competition for stimulating input and inhibiting output to the GPi via STN and STR, respectively. When the GPi is inhibited, this releases the inhibition it exerts on THL, which then allows THL to become spontaneously active. Active thalamic neurons then cause a reversion of activity between SMA and THL. This results in sustained activity over long periods of time which can be switched off by removing the inhibition of GPi from the STR, thereby positively stimulating GPi, again inhibiting THL. This removes the possibility of a retroreflective activity between SMA and THL. The net effect of the complete basal ganglion is a de-inhibitor.  1, The ACTION network, where an SMA is an additional motor area, PMC a pre-motor cortex, STN a subthalamic nucleus, GPe an external area of globus pallidus, GPi an internal area of globus pallidus, THL a thalamus, STR a striatum, IN (ON) is an input layer and OUT (OUT) is an output layer. Open arrows indicate stimulating weights, full arrows indicate inhibitory compounds. The advantage of this hierarchical structure of ACTION networks is the reusability of low order modules by many scheduling modules. A complete sequence is learned only once, there need not be a number of scheduling modules that produce exactly the same sequence. However, a user can solve a particular task in a number of different ways, depending on what the work entails. Thus, in a group of sequences that can solve the same task, there can be subsequences that are common. Rather than representing the subsequence by many low order modules, it is advantageous, due to space and speed, to reuse the low order module that can already generate the subsequence.4shows four scheduling modules, which are all possible user solutions for a particular task, sharing common subsequences.  4, The arrangement of reusable low order scheduling modules; each one  Box an ACTION network of the form of1represents. 4. The rough doubling of the average number of trials from length 4 (5.15 trials) to length 6 (9.5) to length 8 (20.45) indicates that, on average, 40 trials are required to train the importance of 10 tasks.  5. Thus, the sequences on which the system is trained: email management, open email, answer, archive and then write report, open word processor, save, close. The email sequence is trained first. title: Hypertext concept notation for dynamically constructing a sentence to respond to a user request
abstract: Use of concepts to dynamically query a user and construct a sentence for responding to a user request. The use of hypertext concept notation permits the linking of related concepts through concept identifiers. The constructed sentence can be dynamically changed by a user selecting a representation of a concept within the sentence, either a complete sentence or one in the process of being constructed. The data for the selected concept can be updated and the new data inserted into the sentence using the links provided by the concept identifiers.

title: Method and apparatus for generating normalized representations of strings
abstract: A method generates normalized representations of strings, in particular sentences. The method, which can be used for translation, receives an input string. The input string is subjected to a first operation out of a plurality of operating functions for linguistically processing the input string to generate a first normalized representation of the input string that includes linguistic information. The first normalized representation is then subjected to a second operation for replacing linguistic information in the first normalized representation by abstract variables and to generate a second normalized representation.

title: System and method for embedment of emotive content in modern text processing, publishing and communication
abstract: Aspects of the invention provide ways to include emotive content in written communication. The emotive content serves many needs not currently addressed in written word computer applications and text generation aids such as word processors, web publishers, email, file archives, faxes, cell phones, PDAs other applications. Adding emotive content to messages adds information, which can help to interpret and amplify the text message, improve the message integrity and fidelity of communication. Emotional content can contain and convey the subliminal messages, which are vital to a user's interaction with one another via modern communication technologies. Aspects of the invention provide ways for the sender or author to add emotional content, which can capture, maintain, and focuses a receiver's interest.Current expression of emotive content and emotive intensity in written word are rarely used because of lack of writing ability, lack of facilitation or lack of capability. An aspect of the invention provides mechanisms, which facilitate user emotive embedment in the written word without regard to personal language expression and language manipulation skills, vocabulary size or writing style.Aspects of the invention provide sets of emotive primitives, mechanisms and techniques to manipulate these primitives to represent emotive states and emotive intensities while “co-existing” with the actual textual message in the communications. These are primarily done through the use of face glyphs, colors, animation, fonts and also sets of “feeling” words.

title: Vehicular component control using wireless switch assemblies
abstract: Control system for controlling adjustable components in a vehicle using wireless switch assemblies or other input devices which provide input to the control system to enable the control system to control the components based on the input. The control system includes an interrogator arranged to transmit RF signals having identification data associated with the input devices such that upon transmission of each RF signal, the input devices with matching identification data can provide responsive signals. Various types of input devices are envisioned and one type is a manually activated RFID switch assembly which provides output based on pressure applied by the occupant of the vehicle to an exposed surface and includes an RF transmission component arranged to wirelessly transmit an indication of the application of pressure to the exposed surface.

title: Secure messaging systems and methods using intelligent probabilistic volatility servers
abstract: Key features of these methods, apparatus, and designs include (but are not limited to) innovations and implementations of futures securities; the notion of Type I, Type II, and Type III futures contracts custom tailored to specific clienteles; the notion of tickets and coupons as tradable futures contracts; the notion of bifurcation; the notion of redeemable bundles; and notion of realization of the futures market on the Internet; the apparatus of an Internet-based trading interface and engine; the notion of cookie-cutter futures electronic Internet-based futures markets for each security; the feature of maximal reliance on the Internet; and the business concept of “profitability without the need for high trading volume.”

title: Data security system and method responsive to electronic attacks
abstract: An adaptive method, system and program for securing data against a plurality of electronic and environmental events directed at computers utilizes a hacking monitor which generates attack warnings (such as a hacking warning) dependent upon the severity of the attack. Based upon these warnings, data is filtered to extract security sensitive words etc. and the extract and remainder data (if necessary) is stored in assigned memory. Full or partial reconstruction is permitted, manually or automatically, with a security clearance. Encryption is typically used dependent upon the warning. The information processing system includes a filter which is adjusted based upon the degree of attack warning to extract security sensitive words. A storage system stores extracted data and remainder data (if necessary) based upon the level of the warning and a compiler is used to reconstruct the data in the presence of the appropriate security clearance level.

title: Method for detecting Cheyne-Stokes respiration in patients with congestive heart failure
abstract: The present invention provides a diagnostic tool for detection of Cheyne-Stokes Respiration (CSR). This invention also provides a method for development of the diagnostic tool. The method comprises the steps of performing overnight oximetry recordings in patients suspected of sleep disordered breathing. Spectral analysis is performed on the oximetry recordings to obtain a set of parameters which can be used in the construction of a classification tree and a trained neural network. The diagnostic tools of the present invention can be used for classification of a patient as having CSR or obstructive sleep apnea.

title: Method and apparatus for facilitating refinement of a search
abstract: A receiver receives from a search engine search results consisting of at least one search item associated with at least one context item relating to the search item. A modifier modifies the search results by associating at least one context item with data for enabling the user to cause the search results to be filtered in accordance with that context item by selecting that context item. A supplier supplies the modified search results to the user.

title: System and method to aid diagnoses using cross-referenced knowledge and image databases
abstract: The present invention is a method and apparatus for increasing the usefulness of visual knowledge in a number of applications. It distills the relationships between characteristics and hypotheses into database form, thereby organizing visual information in a manner suitable to aid the user in the investigation of the various hypotheses (medical diagnosis, pill identification, plant/animal identification, cause of death, cause of accident, etc.). The invention sidesteps unresolved issues around knowledge engineering by not automating a decision making process. Rather, the present invention utilizes a relational database to dynamically respond to textual and visual findings as an aid to assist a user reaching a reasoned conclusion based upon information available by direct observation and comparison with stored image and textual data.

title: Data mining techniques for enhancing regional product allocation management
abstract: A computer method for enhancing regional product allocation management. The method includes the steps of providing a demand database comprising a compendium of individual demand history; providing a supply database comprising a compendium of at least one of regional product allocation management solutions, regional product allocation information, and regional product allocation diagnostics; and, employing a data mining technique for interrogating the demand and supply databases for generating an output data stream, the output data stream correlating demand problem with supply solution.

title: Unsupervised machine learning-based mathematical model selection
abstract: The invention provides an automated method for identifying an optimal or near optimal mathematical model to describe observed data including: a) the definition of a candidate model search space, b) methods for searching said candidate model search space to identify the optimal or near optimal model within said candidate model search space. The present invention includes algorithms for writing the computer code needed to implement and evaluate candidate models in the software package NONMEM.

title: System and method for writing analysis using the linguistic discourse model
abstract: A technique for writing analysis using the theory of discourse that categorizes text into content, operator and modifier text building units and provides for relating the categorized text building units together using coordination, subordination and binary relationships. A graphical representation of the discourse can be shown since the structural representation of discourse created by the interrelationships can be easily displayed. The analysis and graphical visualization of the writing structure of texts helps writers to analyze and compare writings.

title: Place-specific buddy list services
abstract: An information service provides search and notifications to inform when certain people (e.g., friends, family, business contacts, etc.) are nearby so as to facilitate communications with those people. Users may define lists of people whose locations may be tracked by positioning equipment based on personal communications/computing devices carried by the people. The information service processes this people and place data to identify those of the listed people that are in the user's vicinity, and provide notifications and user-initiated search results informing the user such as via the user's personal communications/computing device.

title: Electrical stimulation of tissue for therapeutic and diagnostic purposes
abstract: Electrobiological stimulation is carried out transcranially by applying high frequency squarewave bursts exhibiting no d.c. term across the cranial region. Such stimulation is commenced employing ramp generators and positive and negative voltage converters which evolve the requisite baseform and burst frequencies having a voltage waveform which is square in nature. Both voltage and current are sensed and subjected to comparator logic in conjunction with predetermined thresholds and windows. Overcurrent detection and overvoltage detection is provided in hard wired fashion to assure rapid shutdown response. D.C offset detection is provided along with waveform balance tests to further assure the safety of the system. Diagnostic procedures as well as therapeutic procedures may be carried out with a system version which provides for the application of a stimulus in conjunction with safety monitoring and controller based development of stimulating waveforms, all of which exhibits no d.c. term. Feed point voltage waveforms and current waveforms are mathematically processed and compared for diagnostic analysis.

title: Stroke-based input of characters from an arbitrary character set
abstract: A method and apparatus for assigning a relatively large character set to a small keyboard. The apparatus includes a keyboard having a plurality of keys in a rectangular array. Each key is assigned to a stroke similar to handwriting strokes. A virtual keyboard is described with two alternate configurations. Combinations of keystrokes are used to resolve the characters with the order of keystrokes determined by analogy to scanning the character under the method.

title: Vehicle rain sensor
abstract: An apparatus and a method for detecting moisture, such as rain on a vehicle, wherein a sensor acquires an optical image from a region of interest and produces the data to a microprocessor, the microprocessor processes the acquired optical image and selects an algorithm to evaluate the acquired optical image in order to determine whether sufficient moisture exists on the vehicle to warrant action such as activating windshield wipers.

title: Signal processing technique
abstract: A signal processing technique for generating separated signal components incorporates the steps of correlating basis vectors with input data to produce output vectors, applying a non-linear function to the output vectors to produce non-linearized vectors, and convolving the non-linearized vectors with the basis vectors to produce separated signal components. Each vector may comprise a set of one-dimensional channel vectors. Separated signal components are combined to form an input signal reconstruction and an anomaly signal indicating deviation of the reconstruction from the associated input signal. Basis vectors are determined by training which involves use of weighting factors referred to as basis scales. When used to scale separated signal components in the production of reconstruction vectors, basis scales have the effect of reducing a mean squared error between such vectors and associated input data used to derive them.

title: System and methods for controlling automatic scrolling of information on a display or screen
abstract: A system for controlling the automatic scrolling of information on a computer display or screen is disclosed. The system includes a gimbaled sensor system for following the position of the user's head and user's eye, and scroll activating interface algorithm to find screen gaze coordinates implemented so the scrolling function is performed based upon the screen gaze coordinates of the user's eye relative to a certain activation area(s) on the display or screen. A method of controlling automatic scrolling of information on a display or screen by a user is also disclosed. The method generally includes the acts of finding a screen gaze coordinate on the display or screen of the user, determining whether the screen gaze coordinate is within at least one activated control region, and activating scrolling to provide a desired display of information when the gaze direction is within at least one activated control region.

title: Apparatus and methods for facilitating treatment of tissue via improved delivery of energy based and non-energy based modalities
abstract: Methods and apparatus for accessing and treating regions of the body are disclosed herein. Using an endoscopic device having an automatically controllable proximal portion and a selectively steerable distal portion, the device generally may be advanced into the body through an opening. The distal portion is selectively steered to assume a selected curve along a desired path within the body which avoids contact with tissue while the proximal portion is automatically controlled to assume the selected curve of the distal portion. The endoscopic device can then be used for accessing various regions of the body which are typically difficult to access and treat through conventional surgical techniques because the device is unconstrained by “straight-line” requirements. Various applications can include accessing regions of the brain, thoracic cavity, including regions within the heart, peritoneal cavity, etc., which are difficult to reach using conventional surgical procedures.

title: Host cells containing multiple integration vectors
abstract: A host cell obtained by clonal selection comprising a genome, in which said genome comprises at least 10 copies of a pseudotyped retroviral vector, wherein said retroviral vector comprises at least one exogenous gene functionally linked to an internal promoter at long terminal repeats. 'and 3' of said retroviral vector, wherein said gene encodes a secreted protein, in which said host cell characterizes because it synthesizes at least 1 picogram of said exogenous protein per day.

title: Apparatus and method for natural language processing
abstract: The present invention provides an apparatus and method for natural language processing capable of providing an appropriate result of natural language processing. More specifically, the present invention provides a natural language processing apparatus for achieving a syntax analysis and/or a syntax generation by using natural language patterns with, at least, pattern name and pattern component. The natural language processing apparatus comprises dictionary reference means for picking up one or more natural language patterns applicable for the syntax analysis and/or the syntax generation among the natural language patterns prepared in a pattern dictionary in advance, pattern inspection means for inspecting whether the applicable natural language patterns meet a tree structure or not, and pattern application means for applying the natural language patterns to the tree structure if the natural language patterns meet the tree structure.

title: Expert system for loop qualification of XDSL services
abstract: A technique for qualification of loops for new digital subscriber line services (DSL) involves use of an expert system, such as a neural network. A database of loop characteristic information and performance data enables the expert system to train or learn how to predict performance for future loops. In response to data characterizing a new loop to be qualified, the trained expert system predicts digital subscriber line performance for the new loop. Typically, the prediction enables classification of service capacity for the new loop into one of several classes corresponding to levels of DSL service offered through the network. The database for use by the expert system is updated as each newly qualified loop is brought into service and actual performance for that loop is known.

title: Automatic labeling of unlabeled text data
abstract: A method of automatically labeling of unlabeled text data can be practiced independent of human intervention, but that does not preclude manual intervention. The method can be used to extract relevant features of unlabeled text data for a keyword search. The method of automated labeling of unlabeled text data uses a document collection as a reference answer set. Members of the answer set are converted to vectors representing centroids of unknown groups of unlabeled text data. Unlabeled text data are clustered relative to the centroids by a nearest neighbor algorithm and the ID of the relevant answer is assigned to all documents in the cluster. At this point in the process, a supervised machine learning algorithm is trained on labeled data, and a classifier for assigning labels to new text data is output. Alternatively, a feature extraction algorithm may be run on classes generated by the step of clustering, and search features output which index the unlabeled text data.

title: TNF-αvariants
abstract: The invention relates to novel proteins with TNF-α antagonist activity and nucleic acids encoding these proteins. The invention further relates to the use of the novel proteins in the treatment of TNF-α related disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis.

title: Transmitting information given constrained resources
abstract: Prioritizing text such as e-mail messages, given constrained resources, is disclosed. In one embodiment, a method first receives a plurality of messages, such as e-mail messages. The method prioritizes the messages, based on a predetermined criteria given a constrained resource. The method then outputs the messages to a user, as prioritized given the constrained resource. Specific constrained resources include limited bandwidth, limited storage space, and limited time in which to receive the texts. Embodiments include policies that include priority-sensitive truncation and summarization. Furthermore, in one embodiment, if context is detected, the priorities for caching are affected. In another embodiment, the likelihood that a user already knows all or part of the information being transmitted is considered.

title: Method for determining location of gastrointestinal bleeding
abstract: A method for determining if blood in a stool sample originated from the upper or lower gastrointestinal tract. This includes a method for purifying and concentrating hemoglobin and its products from a stool sample to allow a simple and sensitive spectrophotometric analysis. A rapid, noninvasive determination of whether the blood originated from an upper gastrointestinal or lower gastrointestinal site is made on the basis of changes in the absorption spectra of hemoglobin that occur when hemoglobin is exposed to a highly acidic environment.

title: Closed-loop neuromodulation for prevention and treatment of cardiac conditions
abstract: A method and apparatus to provide therapy to a patient for protecting cardiac tissue from insult is disclosed. The method comprises delivering closed loop electrical stimulation to one or more predetermined portions of a portion of excitable tissue of the spinal cord of a patient; and monitoring one or more physiologic indices of the body. That is, a closed-loop feedback controller is used to apply electrical stimulation to preselected regions of the spinal cord of a patient's body based upon one or more aspects of the physiologic indices.

title: Multivariate analysis of green to ultraviolet spectra of cell and tissue samples
abstract: This invention relates to methods for processing in vivo skin auto-fluorescence spectra for determining blood glucose levels. The invention also relates to methods of classifying cells or tissue samples or quantifying a component of a cell or tissue using a multivariate classification or quantification model.

title: Branch on bid searching method and apparatus
abstract: In a multi-unit combinatorial auction, reverse auction, or exchange, a number of bids can be received, with each bid including one or more items and for each item a desired quantity thereof. Each bid also includes a price. A number of unique combinations of bids can be formed from the received bids, and the one combination of bids which represents the best value in terms of an auction setting, a reverse auction setting and/or an exchange setting can be determined. Thereafter, the bids forming this combination can be declared the winning bids of the auction, reverse auction or exchange.

title: Braking process in an integrated traction drive and braking system
abstract: BACKGROUND AND SUMMARY OF THE INVENTION The The present invention relates generally to electrically controlled pneumatic Train brakes, computer controlled train braking systems and propulsion systems and in particular the braking in the brake and drive systems as well as their integration. computerized Brake systems are well known, such as the New York Air Corporation deliver CCBI and CCBII. These systems offer a computer control of the pneumatic control unit for by the entire train running air pressure lines. This allows the pneumatic control of locomotive and individual wagon brakes. Lately, the industry has become electrically controlled to provide electropneumatic brakes on every wagon. This has led to the electrically controlled pneumatic ECP system, which is independent of computer-controlled braking system is. An overview of such a system is EP-60, available at the New York Air Brake Corporation. So as present implemented, running the ECP system in the locomotive parallel to that of the conventional pneumatic locomotive train controls. Two brake valves are one of which is the brake valve for pneumatic braking and the other is the ECP brake valve. Be equal for the individual systems used separate displays. The locomotive or the locomotive network does not respond to the brake commands the ECP system, as the locomotives respond to pneumatic signals via lines. Also features the ECP system over its own discrete input from the event recorder and the Locomotive controls for the determination of penalties. The Drive system on the locomotive is also one of the ECP system and Separated from the convention of pneumatic locomotive and train controls System. The Drive system includes the drive and dynamic braking as well various additional functions related to braking, for example Sand scatter and power switch. In general, they are together adjacent locomotives a composite and have a leading locomotive. The leading locomotive supplies the electrical and pneumatic controls to the adjacent ones Locomotives. There is also a distributed power system available at the leading locomotive a composite of the leading locomotive another group is separated by wagons in the train. In the The two leading locomotives have radio transmission over the past communicated. The one from the lead locomotive specified controls are over Transfer radio to the remote management locomotive. This resulted in a doubling of the locomotive controls at both Connected. In WO 99/24298 is a train brake system with a Kabelzugleitung and a brake line and an electropneumatic brake control discloses, which is connected to the brake line and over the Zugleitung emits electro-pneumatic brake signals. In addition includes the train brake system is a drive control system. However will the distributive energy over Radio is delivered to the remote locomotives, and it is not possible to drive information from the remote locomotive to the lead locomotive over the Pass train line. In documentUS 5,303,157For example, there is disclosed a locomotive control system having a single handle that can be moved between a maximum drive position and an idle position. With such single-handle locomotive control, an adequate mix of dynamic and pneumatic braking based on handle movement can be achieved. This system does not show a remote drive controller that transmits a brake request to the leading drive controller and no leading drive controller that transmits a drive signal in response to the brake request from the remote controller. With the implementation of electrically controlled pneumatic or electropneumatic Braking there was a discussion about the desirability of integrating the computer-controlled braking systems in the electrically controlled pneumatic Braking systems. The present system provides integrated operation of brake and drive systems for a train, which is a train brake line, passing through locomotives and wagons on the train, electropneumatic brakes on the train Locomotives and wagons owns, which with the train brake line and connected to a power grid. A brake control on the locomotives gives off brake commands that is a drive system on the locomotives connected to the grid, and a drive control on the locomotives gives drive commands. The method of operating the brake and drive systems includes determining whether the brake command signal is a brake command initiated by the pneumatic or electrical system or a brake command initiated by an operator.  A brake signal and an emergency drive signal are transmitted in the network for emergency brake commands, which are triggered by the pneumatic and electrical system and by the operator. A brake signal is transmitted via the train brake line for brake commands triggered by the operator and the pneumatic system. If the train a leading one and has remote drive control, transmits the leading drive control the remote drive control instructions for the appropriate brake control the remote control for transmission a brake signal over the train brake line for Brake commands triggered by the operator and the pneumatic system. If the remote drive controller transmits a brake request to the leading drive controller, transmits the leading drive system a brake drive signal in response to the brake request. The remote drive control and the drive systems only respond on drive signals. The remote drive control transfers locally recorded pneumatic and electrical system and operator-triggered braking requirements. The remote drive controller transmits the brake request, until the local, which created the braking request event has, stops and the remote drive controller receives a brake signal. The premier Drive control gives the brake request to its brake control off, and the leading one Brake control transmits a brake signal and assigns the leading Drive control to transmit a brake drive signal. The leading brake control has the leading one Drive control on, to the remote drive control instructions for the to transfer appropriate brake control to the remote controller, about a brake signal over the train brake line for Operator and pneumatic system-triggered brake commands to transmit. If the brake system comprises a locomotive brake pipe extending through adjacent locomotives extends, and the locomotive brakes too connected to the locomotive brake line transmits a locomotive brake signal via the locomotive brake line for train and locomotive brake commands. braking signals can over the Transfer train brake line be, and drive signals using radio, if the Train is operated in a pneumatic mode. Brake signals and drive signals can about that Network are transmitted, when the train is operating in an electrical mode. The System includes a single brake control, the locomotive and Train brake commands outputs. A first brake control process is with the brake control connected and transmits a wagon brake signal above the Net for Train brake. A second brake control process is with the brake control connected and transmits a locomotive brake signal over the Locomotive brake line for train and locomotive brake commands. The Brake system can have a pneumatic and an electric mode to have. The first brake control process transmits wagon brake signals via the Network in electrical mode, and the second brake control process transmits wagon brake signals over the Pull brake line for the pneumatic mode. The second brake control process transmits locomotive brake signals via the Locomotive brake pipe in both mode. The Brake control gives a system-triggered brake command or a Operator-initiated Brake command. The first brake control process transmits a brake signal via the Network for System and operator triggered Braking commands. The second brake control process transmits an emergency brake signal over the Train and locomotive brake lines for operator-initiated brake commands and those of the pneumatic system. The brake control has one leading and trailing mode and gives the brake command signals only in the leading one Mode off. Other Goals, advantages and innovations of the present invention will be apparent the following detailed description of the invention in a joint consideration with the accompanying drawings. The emergency state remains active until the emergency state timer has expired and the automatic brake lever of the air brake system has been returned to the emergency state position for resetting. The emergency or emergency brake request remains active until the DP controlled unit receives an appropriate DP emergency brake response from the leading DP unit. This releases the local PCS command and the ECP and pneumatic emergency request to the leading unit will be removed. At this point, the DP controlled unit only follows the ECP guidance commands, and the DP command commands are also routed locally to the ECP (HEU), and the local air brake system for emergency status control, PCS control and EBV control. The ECP function (HEU) returns control to the operator or handle. If the emergency status event is local to the leading DP unit, the ECP (HEU) function transmits the train brake command on the EP line40, indicated by arrow4, and transmits an ECP emergency status command back to the by arrow5displayed leading DP function. The operation then continues for a remotely located emergency event to cause emergency conditions on the leading DP unit and all DP controlled units. The release of the emergency condition event, including the timing of the timer, occurs at the leading DP unit which is routed locally through the ECP function as well as remotely through the leading DP function, as indicated by arrow13displayed. The control27.26provides penalty brake commands as in7shown. For these penalty brake commands in electric control mode, penalty brake command signals are sent to the TCC control42given to transmit a wagon brake signal on the network for penalty brake commands. Penalty braking is generally a full service brake command. As with other wagon brake signals in the network, the brake line remains21loaded. A penalty confirmation from the TCC42to the IPM27is required. If it is not received, the IPM commands27a pneumatic emergency application using the EP control unit20, The control27Also determines whether the suppression brake command has taken place to remove or prevent the operation of a penalty brake. This is the suppression position of the automatic brake handle of the electric brake valve26, If the suppression brake commands occur during a penalty brake command, control sends27.26no control or brake command signals to the controller42or removes and interrupts any penalty application that controls42on the EP train line40provides. As is well known, the controller gives27.26a power down signal to the locomotive propulsion system for penalty brake commands. In older systems, the movement of the automatic brake handle to the suppression position causes a brake pipe shortening which operates the train brakes. This is undesirable and avoided by the present system which uses the suppression position only as an electrical control signal and in the brake line21No pneumatic results produced. As can be seen, the brake pipe in an ECP train is primarily an air supply and is not used for brake control. In the current system, the brake pipe21used as a backup to allow pneumatic operation of train brakes as well as operator and pneumatic system initiated emergency conditions. For future acceptance of ECP brakes by the industry have the train brake line21and the locomotive lines22and23possibly no control functions. In an EP-only train are the independent locomotive brake lines22and the actuation locomotive line23eliminated. All signals are transmitted via the EP trainline40sent out. Consequently, trainline brake signals are addressed separately to wagons and locomotives, and special locomotive brake signals are addressed only to locomotives. It should also be noted in the present system - even in those who use the independent brake line22with or without the control line23- that those locomotives that have EP brakes, preferably their brake signal via the electric brake line40receive. The locomotives, which have no EP brakes, receive the signals pneumatically via the independent or locomotive brake line22, The locomotives that are not adjacent to the leading locomotive and not by the independent brake line22are connected to other locomotives, receive their signal either by radio33or the remote locomotive can have EP capability and their signals on the EP trainline40receive. It can then pneumatically control other contiguous locomotives in its composite, if through an independent line22are connected. Another example of a remote locomotive would be a sliding locomotive attached at the end of the train when needed to handle a particular grade. These locomotives would be EP-equipped and would use their locomotive brake signals from the EP train line40to take. This would include automatic, independent and bail-off release commands. The brake control27is started in conventional or pneumatic mode. In order to be switched to electric mode, it must be selected as the leading locomotive and then switched to electrical mode. The integration or coordination of the electrically controlled pneumatics or the ECP system by the computer-controlled braking system makes it possible to increase safety. The computer-controlled braking system can determine whether the electrically controlled pneumatics42in operation or not, and if not, the pneumatic control of the brake line21provide braking power throughout the train. By providing a single brake control valve26and a single display32In addition, the operator in a state of emergency does not need to decide whether to switch from electrical control to pneumatic control. The operator uses a simple handle and a simple display and selects whether pneumatic or electrical control is used. When the electrically controlled brakes are not in operation, the system automatically switches to the pneumatic control without additional input from the operator. As a result, integration not only increases the reliability of the two systems, but also substantially eliminates operator error. Though the present invention has been described and illustrated in detail, but it is emphatic to point out that this is for illustrative and example purposes only done and no restrictions can be derived from it. title: Traffic congestion management when providing realtime information to service providers
abstract: Methods, systems, and arrangements facilitate information interexchange between a telecommunications network and an information service provider. For example, a business-to-business (B2B) engine includes one or more logic modules for interfacing with the telecommunications network and with the information service provider. The B2B engine facilitates the reporting of, e.g., realtime information from the telecommunications network to the information service provider. This realtime information may include subscriber unit location that is proactively sent by the subscriber unit to the B2B engine for forwarding to the information service provider. To avoid possibly congesting the telecommunications network, the B2B engine is empowered to monitor the number of proactively-transmitted location messages and to limit them if they exceed a defined threshold.

title: Vision testing system
abstract: A method and apparatus are provided for testing the vision of a human subject using a series of eye tests (310). A test setup procedure (312) is run to adjust the settings of a display device (1914) such that graphic objects displayed on the device (1914) conform to a pre-defined appearance. A series of preliminary tests (314), static tests (316) and dynamic tests (318) are displayed on the device (1914), and the responses of the subject are recorded. The tests (310) may be run remotely, for example over the Internet. No lenses are required to run the tests (310).

title: Methods and apparatus for predictive analysis
abstract: Methods and apparatus for predictive analytics generally comprise one or more artificial agents and an agent factory. An artificial agent may be responsive to at least one of an internal data set and an external data set. Further, an artificial agent may produce a correlation data set relating an outcome data set and at least one of the internal data set and the external data set. In addition, an artificial agent may produce a predictability value corresponding to the correlation data set. The agent factory may be responsive to the outcome data set. Also, the agent factory may produce the artificial agent in response to the outcome data set.

title: User interface providing automatic organization and filtering of search criteria
abstract: A user interface for querying and displaying records from a database employs a physical metaphor for the process of constructing queries and viewing results. The criteria are represented in displays as symbols that can be included in a query. The display of the symbols are ranked in terms of their respective utility, where the utility is inferred from the commands received to generate the queries. In one embodiment, the ranking is based on frequency of use. The ranking may be indicated by various display effects. For example, in an embodiment, the search criteria are indicated as strings of beads in a three-dimensional scene, each bead representing a criterion and each string representing a different category. For example the criteria, drama, action, suspense, and horror may be included in a category of genre. Criteria are selected to form a query by moving corresponding beads to a query string which is then submitted to perform the search. Those beads that correspond to highly ranked criteria are shown in the foreground of the scene and those that correspond to lesser ranked criteria are shown in the background. The beads can be rotated from background to foreground with suitable commands.

title: Procedure for increasing the transmission rate in a telecommunications network
abstract: Procedure for increasing the transmission rate in a small bandwidth telecommunications network comprising several data and voice transmission stations (A, B, ...) characterized in that the communications are carried out in conference and in alternation, being received any broadcast of one of the stations of the network by all other stations, each of the stations in the network has the same rights to intervene on a synchronization subchannel and because it consists in multiplexing in time the subchannels of data (D1, D2 , ...) and voice (P1, P2, ...) with a synchronization subchannel (S) to form a frame consisting of an alternation of data, voice and synchronization slots, each data slot comprising , voice and synchronization a first part reserved for synchronization with a synchronization signal emitted by one of the stations of the network that is in broadcast, devoting the rest of the duration of the range ra to the emission of the three subchannels mentioned above.

title: Device and method for cataloging textual information.
abstract: Device and method for cataloging textual information The invention relates to a method for cataloging, or searching in, textual information, as well as a device therefor. Such a method is generally known. For example, it is known to catalog textual information by means of so-called "natural language processing". The interrelation between words is analyzed on the basis of applicable grammar rules, and in this way connections between words that together form concepts 10 are recognized. However, such an analysis takes a lot of computing time, is complex and is language dependent. In addition, methods are known in which all words, with the exception of stop words, are indexed individually. However, a great deal of information is lost in this process, especially with regard to terms composed of several words. Other known methods, such as described in US-5,931,907, US-5,754,938, EP-A-860,785 or WO-A-OO / 17781, among others, use keywords. The disadvantage of this is that the use of wrong keywords in the search can lead to missing information. In addition, a keyword can be used in, for example, a document that has nothing to do with searched documents. For example, the use of the 101 51 51 2 keyword "xenotransplantation" in search may result in missing references using the word "xenographic procedure". In addition, truncation to the search term "xeno" can lead to far too many irrelevant hits. Still other known methods, such as described in WO-A-98/38560, among others, use automatically generated word clusters and terms. in such methods, the editing of many texts recognizes coherence and relationships between words. When 10 certain words often occur together, these words can be recognized as belonging to one concept. The known methods are therefore either too slow or too inaccurate, for instance to be applied interactively and possibly by an inexperienced user. It is an object of the invention to provide a method of the type mentioned in the preamble, which is suitable, inter alia, for interactive application, for application by an inexperienced user, or for application in a distributed environment, such as for instance the internet or an intranet. These goals are achieved, and other advantages are achieved, with a method of cataloging textual information or generating a knowledge profile therefrom, wherein: a user enters textual information into a computer, further provided with software; The software includes a routine that divides the textual information into words, and a routine that searches the words of the textual information in at least one structured data file contained in memory means in the computer, which structured data file comprises words containing per word references to 3 5 concepts; the software is provided with a routine that searches word by word in the textual information for all corresponding words in the structured data file and subsequently links the related concepts from the structured data file per word; 5 and the software is provided with a routine which then clusters concepts into a list of keywords or umbrella keywords by means of clustering; and the software is provided with a routine 10 which subsequently presents the list of keywords to the user in interactive as a knowledge profile or category. The invention further relates to a computer system provided with input means, output means and connection means for connection to other computer systems, wherein the computer system is arranged for carrying out the method according to one or more of the preceding claims. Because the method according to the invention uses structured data files in the cataloging, it is possible to catalog textual information in a fast, efficient manner, which is possibly suitable for interactive application by an inexperienced user, for instance via a distributed environment such as the internet or an intranet. Cataloging according to the invention includes indexing textual information and making textual information findable. For example, the terms or keywords associated with the textual information may be abstract representations of multiple words. An example of this is the International Patent Classification System (IPC), in which terms, often several words long, are indicated using a code. In one embodiment of the present invention, the terms in the structured data file refer to keywords, with the routine clustering the keywords then clustering the keywords. In addition, several terms in the structured data file can refer to the same keyword. A term can also refer to several keywords. Preferably, the structured data file is a structured glossary such as a thesaurus or metathesaurus. In the further text, when the word thesaurus is used, implicitly also metathesaurus is meant. In treasury, concepts are arranged according to a hierarchical system of umbrella or generic concepts, including increasingly specific concepts. This creates a kind of tree structure of higher-level, overarching concepts, with branches to increasingly specific concepts. In the method according to the invention, if desired, use can be made of treasury from different knowledge areas and this treasury can be combined into one large thesaurus. Clustering preferably takes place on the basis of connections within sentences. This makes a very fast method possible, while experiments have shown that very good accuracy was nevertheless achieved. Clustering searches for common concepts, and possibly corresponding umbrella concepts to which words in a sentence refer back. 25 This is repeated until no more common concepts are found. In order to determine which terms in the list of terms are to be shown to a user, all terms in the list of terms are provided with weights which indicate the mutual importance. Preferably, the weights include quantities relating to the frequency with which the terms occur in the textual information, the specificity of the terms and a measure of the certainty of the occurrence of the term (i.e. the sensitivity) in the textual information. The weights represent statistical properties of each concept. This includes the specificity, the 101 51 51 5 sensitivity, the number of alternatives that appear in the textual information and the textual simularity. On the basis of the weights, it can be determined, for example, which terms are shown to the user from the list of terms. In order to increase the accuracy even further, it is preferable if the user can interactively adjust the weights, specifically the relative weights of the terms shown to each other. In order to make the textual information easily searchable, the list of terms per concept includes information with regard to the location of the textual information. As a result, the list of terms with the location can be included in a database, and the textual information can easily be retrieved.
