The circuit compares the two input currents from the WTA circuit by using NMOS transistors which perform electrical mathematical functions by manipulating the currents. The end result is that the difference of the two currents is compared with a reference current and a voltage level is outputted. The reference current is adjustable, and the invention also provides a WTA circuit with weighted inputs, and the ability to select between a 1-WTA, and a 2-WTA configuration. The invention therefore solves the problems of prior art by being capable of properly selecting current levels or rejecting current levels which are too close in value, with a voltage reject signal.

title: Method and apparatus for synchronising receivers
abstract: A receiver produces complex data samples from a demodulated received signal. The data samples, which may form a preamble identifying a wireless LAN data burst, are arranged in a sequence comprising sub-sequences having a predetermined relationship with each other. A tuning frequency offset is determined by delaying the complex data samples by a plurality of different delay periods, auto-correlating the complex data samples using said different delay periods in order to produce respective auto-correlation outputs, determining a plurality of phase-dependent values each dependent upon phase errors in a respective auto-correlation output and calculating a value representing frequency offset by combining the phase-dependent values in a weighted manner. The preamble can be recognised by using the same delay means. One matched filter is used to detect a particular sub-sequence, the output is fed to the delay means, and a second matched filter receives the outputs of the delay means to detect sub-sequences having the correct timing relationship.

title: LCD with adaptive luminance intensifying function and driving method thereof
abstract: Disclosed is an LCD having an adaptive luminance intensifying function and driving method thereof. A timing controller checks features of externally provided image data, and when they are found to be moving pictures, it determines a luminance level required from the image data and outputs a luminance level control signal, and when they are found to be still images, outputs a predetermined luminance signal. A backlight driver outputs a high-potential backlight driving voltage to the backlight unit when a luminance control signal of high-luminance level driving is provided by the timing controller, and outputs a constant level luminance signal when a constant luminance signal is input. As a result, by selecting a plurality of portions of the displayed screen and tracking and monitoring the changes of the image data, features of the images are defined and application conditions of the luminance intensifying function are determined to control the luminance level of the backlight and outputs of gamma voltage levels. Accordingly, the contrast of a display screen is improved and the power consumption is

title: METHOD AND DEVICE FOR GENERATING AN AC VOLTAGE FOLLOWING AN INPUT DATA CURRENT
abstract: <Desc / Clms Page number 1>         The invention relates to a method for generating a powerful an input data stream, eg. B. in Sony Consumer Standard @ 2s format, the following AC voltage according to the preamble of claim 1, and a device for performing the method.       In the consumer audio sector, for example, the power for the loudspeakers is transmitted via correspondingly voluminous copper wires. In addition to high costs, these cables also act as transmit antennas for high-frequency interference when switching amplifiers, so-called D amplifiers, are used. As part of a larger, progressive concept, a D amplifier, to which a digital data stream is fed via fiber optics, is built into the loudspeaker housing. The D-amplifier of such a loudspeaker is supplied by means of a mains connection, and must also meet strict electromagnetic standards with the environment with regard to the mains feedback.       In known solutions of this type, the input data stream is always converted into an analog signal, which is then amplified and the amplified signal is subsequently converted back into a digital signal. However, a loss of quality due to repeated implementation cannot be avoided.       In addition, the efficiency of non-switching analog amplifiers is relatively low at around 50%.      On the other hand, more than 90% is already achieved with power electronics or switching amplifiers. With the D amplifier, an analog voltage at the input is modulated with a fixed frequency, the switching frequency of the D amplifier, pulse widths (PWM). This PWM voltage is amplified in the PWM output stage of the D amplifier by switching transistors on and off with high efficiency. The filter size of a D amplifier is determined by the lower hearing threshold (15 Hz). The efficiency is significantly influenced by the switching frequency. The switching frequency must be a multiple of the upper hearing threshold (20 kHz).       The spectrum of the amplified PWM voltage naturally has a high switching frequency component and high harmonic components, which now have to be completely filtered out again in order to obtain a powerful, undistorted analog voltage at the load. It is necessary to avoid pulse inaccuracies by appropriate feedback.       D-amplifiers with an analog input and passive filters are known from the prior art.      The phase shift of a bandpass filter and the complex loudspeaker load very quickly set the strong negative feedback, desirable for low distortions, due to instabilities.       Another problem with known D-type amplifiers of this type is that DC voltage supplies, which essentially draw a sinusoidal current from a network, so-called power factor correction circuits (hereinafter referred to as PFC for short) provide rippled DC voltage, which is a considerable one Ripple portion, or has ripple. The ripple has a frequency that corresponds to 2n times the frequency of the network, where n is the number of phases of the network connected to a full-wave rectifier circuit.      A noticeable ripple in the voltage supply makes it difficult to amplify the input signal largely without distortion. To smooth the ripple, DCDC stages are common, but they require a relatively high level of circuitry.       The aim of the invention is to avoid these disadvantages and to propose a method of the type mentioned at the beginning which enables amplification with sinusoidal current consumption of the DC voltage supply from the network with high efficiency, the amplified voltage corresponding very precisely to the input data stream ,       According to the invention, this is achieved in a method of the type mentioned at the outset by the characterizing features of claim 1.       The proposed measures prevent conversion into an analog signal and at the same time ensure that the amplified signal largely corresponds to the input data stream even when the DC voltage supply is sinusoidal, or if the DC voltage applied to the D-amplifier ripples considerably equivalent.       The amplified output signal can be derived using any algorithm. For example, the derivation of a digital signal from the amplified output    <Desc / Clms Page number 2>   signal according to the algorithm of an adaptive delta modulation, a superimposed algorithm for reducing the effective switching frequency can also be provided, or according to an advanced pulse code modulation. The algorithms given above are only examples.       Another object of the invention is to propose a device for carrying out the method according to the invention.       Starting from a device according to the preamble of claim 2, the characterizing features of claim 2 are therefore proposed.       The proposed measures result in a very simple structure, with the digital control loop ensuring a very precise comparison of the amplified voltage with the input data stream. Fluctuations in the DC voltage supply of the D amplifier are also recognized and taken into account.       Without the addition of the signal corresponding to the ripple of the DC voltage supply to the input signal or a signal derived therefrom, the controller would only notice fluctuations in the DC voltage supply after the signal has passed through the device, and filters may also be provided. Within the lead time, all changes in the supply voltage would therefore be passed on directly to the load as amplitude modulation. The proposed measures ensure that changes in the supply voltage to the amplifier stage are counteracted. As a result, the circuitry complexity for the voltage supply can be kept low, even if it consumes an essentially sinusoidal current and therefore only causes a slight network reaction.     So it can be found with simple PFC circuits.       The features of claim 3 result in the advantage that an adaptation to the conditions from the area downstream of the actuator is also possible. This is e.g. B. advantageous in audio systems. So it is possible for the sound reinforcement of a disco the increasing attenuation changes in attenuation and thus changes in the actuator, z. B. a speaker to compensate downstream signal path.       Due to the features of claim 4, the demands on the power supply decrease with little digital circuitry.       The proposed measures can also be used to detect and correct fluctuations in the supply voltage of the power unit. In addition, the voltage source can be constructed more simply and z. B. can only be realized by a simple PFC connected downstream of a rectifier circuit. The computing effort for the comparator and controller can be implemented rather slowly in the microprocessor or quickly in a circuit-programmable IC in a hard-wired computing circuit. Given the high conversion speeds of today's AD converters (eg 90 MHz), a sufficiently short loop throughput time can already be achieved in the latter case, so that a pulse pattern correction is then also carried out with this controller structure.       If filter distortions are also to be corrected, the problem of phase rotation must be solved. This is done in the control loop according to claim 5.       The phase shift can be compensated for by means of a timing element which is very easy to carry out in digital technology. The controller is informed of the setpoint delayed by the filter runtime, so that it arrives at the same time as the feedback digitized output voltage.      As a result, the controller works stably.       Methods are known in which filter distortions are accepted and a fast control loop for pulse pattern generation is provided, which requires an analog input signal.       The features of claim 6 make it possible to generate a pulse pattern, the digital input data stream being processed with high congruence to form a powerful PWM output voltage, and a quality-reducing digital / analog conversion can be dispensed with.       A high-quality energy supply and a correspondingly complex D / A converter (filter) are necessary for high quality requirements.       However, the controller only notices fluctuations in the supply voltage after the cycle time of the D / A converter or filter. All changes to the    <Desc / Clms Page number 3>   Supply voltage passed directly to the load as amplitude modulation, which manifests itself in an insufficient supply voltage rejection (SVR).       Combinations of several control loops according to claims 7 to 9 appear advantageous.       The features of claim 7 result in savings in energy supply and the features in claim 8 result in savings in the D / A converter.       It is particularly advantageous to provide the features of claim 9, which result in savings in the energy supply and D / A converter.       Acceptable results are currently achieved with a negative feedback network to compensate for the switching time errors and complex, tolerance-sensitive and necessarily multi-stage filters and a correspondingly high switching frequency. The fast inner control loop for the pulse pattern correction of the amplifier stage previously required an analog signal or the D / A conversion of a digital input data stream. The required switching frequency of well over 100 kHz and the associated fast commutation processes in the amplifier stage make it more difficult to comply with the standards that have been binding for all products put into circulation in the EEA since January 2, 1996, in particular EN 50081 with regard to Interference emissions from electromagnetic fields.       Due to the features of claim 10 or 11, the D-amplifier can have at least the same quality of the output signal compared to the single-stage solution, e.g. due to the phase-shifted clocking of n power units 5 connected in parallel with the nth of the switching frequency. The switching processes can run more slowly without loss of quality. This increases the electromagnetic compatibility. The switching losses increase, the efficiency remains high compared to the A amplifier. At higher powers (currently around 5 kW upwards), relief circuits can also be used due to the reduced switching frequency, which increases the power density (power that can be transferred per volume of power parts).       In addition, the advantages can be exploited that result from the interconnection of several D amplifier stages without increasing the computing power of the digital control unit by a corresponding multiple. The amplifier stages can be constructed relatively simply.       The invention will now be explained in more detail with reference to the drawing. Show: 1 shows a first embodiment of an amplifier arrangement, 2 to 4 embodiments of a control device, 5 to 8 different embodiments of amplifier arrangements, 9 shows a further exemplary embodiment of a device according to the invention, 10 and 11 further embodiments of a control device, 12 shows an exemplary embodiment for a power section of a D amplifier stage, Fig. 13 schematically shows a controller and 14 shows a further exemplary embodiment of an amplifier arrangement.       Digital data streams with hatched bars and analog data streams with simple lines are shown in all the figures.       The amplifier arrangement or device according to FIG. 1 has an amplifier stage V5, which is shown in more detail in FIG. 8, and which has a control loop 2 or a predictor 2 'which is connected upstream of the amplifier stage V5 to which an actuator 9, for. B. a speaker is connected via an output terminal 8.       The amplifier stage V5 essentially has a series circuit 3 of a mixer 67, which comes from an input data stream 1 'coming from the control loop 2 or the predictor 12, the predictor 12 can also be connected upstream of the control loop 2, and a data stream 61 which, as still will be explained, which corresponds to the ripple of a DC voltage supply of a D-amplifier 5, generates a data stream 1 ″, and an encoder 68, which converts the data stream 1 ″ into a digital signal train 4. This functional block, consisting of the mixer 67 and the encoder, is referred to below as the mixer-encoder circuit 3. This circuit 3 is followed by a D amplifier 5, which amplifies the digital signal train and applies it to a D / A converter 7, which can also be designed as a filter circuit.       The control loop 2 is connected via an A / D converter 20 and a line 31 to the output    <Desc / Clms Page number 4>   terminal 8 connected. The predictor 12 upstream of the control loop 2 is not absolutely necessary, an input of the predictor 12 being acted upon by a signal coming from a microphone 80. This allows changes in an actuator connected to the device, e.g. B. a speaker 9, downstream signal path, z. B. a room sounded by the loudspeaker, e.g. B. a disco, z. B. are caused by a change in the number of people in this room. A larger change in the number of people in a sound-affected room changes the damping and thus the characteristics of the signal path downstream of the loudspeaker.       For example, the control loop can be supplied with a signal from a loudspeaker set up in a disco, which serves as an actuator 9, or from the disco itself. In this case, not only can any distortions caused by the amplifier stage V5 be corrected, but also distortions and influences caused by the downstream route, such as. B. the number of dependent attenuation in the sonicated room.       In this embodiment, the control loop 2 and the predictor 12 are connected upstream of the amplifier stage V5, so that there is one in front of the input data stream 1, 1 ', which precedes in the form of data words with a predetermined number of bits and on the control loop 2, respectively Predictor 12 is present, changed data stream 1 "is present.       A predictor 12 at most temporarily requires a feedback, so that the connection between the microphone 80 and the corresponding input of the predictor 12 can also be temporarily interrupted by means of a switch (not shown). The predictor 12 forms the inverse function of the system behavior z. B. mathematically. It can also consist of a so-called neural network that has the ability to learn, or it can also consist of a cell capable of learning. The basics and theory of neural networks and their structure are known from the relevant literature and do not form part of the invention.       The advantage of a predictor 12 is its robustness against interference, since it does not need constant feedback, and in the expanded possibilities that arise in particular in the case of a neural network capable of learning.       However, a predictor cannot compensate for the noise of a system that changes over time, such as thermal drift, switching time jitter, etc. The transmission behavior of a controlled system that is unchanged over time is realized by means of at least temporary feedback.       For this purpose, the control loop 2 constantly requires the feedback of the signal tapped from point 4 'or of an amplified signal tapped from point 6' and attenuated via the attenuator 10 (FIG. 5). In the circuit according to FIG. 1, the control loop 2 can be designed differently, different examples being shown in FIGS. 2 to 4.       In the embodiment according to FIG. 1, a full-wave rectifier 62, which draws an essentially sinusoidal current from the network 63, is provided for the energy supply of the D amplifier 5 and is connected to a network 63. This rectifier 62 is followed by a power factor correction circuit PFC, which supplies the supply lines 55, 56 of the D amplifier 5.       Capacitors 41, 42 are connected to these two supply lines 55, 56, both of which are connected to ground 40. This prevents the fluctuations in the supply voltages from leading to amplitude modulation of the amplified signal.       2 shows the basic structure of a first embodiment R1 of a control loop 2. In this embodiment, a controller 13, a coding device 16 and a pulse error comparator 14 are provided. The computing power for the controller R3 is provided by a microprocessor.       In the amplifier stages V2 to V4 according to FIGS. 5 to 7 and V6 according to FIG. 9, the effort required for energy supply and amplification is lower at the expense of an increased effort in low-performance control electronics, which has an ever increasing quality of Output voltage at the load, i. H. the actuator 9 guaranteed.       6 has a control loop R3, a control loop R1, the coding unit 3, a D amplifier 5, a D / A converter 7, an attenuator 10 and a converter 20. Filter distortions can also be corrected by the feedback of the output voltage. U. can be dispensed with a filter stage. In addition, a wide variety of filter characteristics can be taken into account in a digitally operating control device without significant additional effort.       FIG. 9 shows an amplifier stage V6 which has a multiplexer 30 and a number n of amplifier stages which can be designed in accordance with the amplifier stages V2 to V5. The multiplexer 30 generates a number of n parts of data streams 1 'from the input data stream 1, each data stream 1' being fed to one of the amplifier stages V2 to V5, the same amplifier stages being expediently provided in each case. The outputs of the n amplifier stages are connected to the output terminal 8 and feed the output voltage 31. The actuator 9, for. B. a loudspeaker is connected either directly via a line 34 or via an interposed filter 33 to the output terminal 8 of the amplifier stage V6.       In the embodiment according to FIG. 9, the D-amplifier can have at least the same quality of the output signal compared to the single-stage solution, e.g. B. due to the phase-shifted clocking of n D-amplifiers 5 connected in parallel with the nth part of the switching frequency. The switching processes can run more slowly without loss of quality. This increases the electromagnetic compatibility. The switching losses increase, the efficiency remains high compared to an A amplifier. With higher performances of z. B. 5kW and more, can also be used due to the reduced switching frequency, relief circuits, whereby the power density per volume of the power parts transferable power is increased.       In the embodiment according to FIG. 10, an amplifier stage V6, which, as can be seen from FIG. 9, comprises a plurality of D amplifiers, is preceded by a regulator R2 or R3 (FIG. 3, FIG. 4), which controls the input data stream 1 and processes the output data stream 21, which is generated by the converter 20, into data stream 35. The voltage at the output terminal 8 of the amplifier stage V6 or the voltage at the load 9 is fed back to the input of the converter 20 by means of a switch 36, which can also be omitted.       In the embodiment according to FIG. 10, the advantages which result from the interconnection of a plurality of D amplifiers can be used without the computing power of the digital control unit having to be increased by a corresponding multiple. The amplifier stage V6 can consist of simple amplifier stages, e.g. B. amplifier stages V5 (Fig. 1).       In the embodiment according to FIG. 10, a changeover switch 32 is also provided, by means of which the output terminal 8 can either be connected via a filter 33 or directly to the load 9.       In the embodiment according to FIG. 11, a predictor 12 is connected upstream of an amplifier stage, which can optionally be an amplifier stage V2, V3, V4, V5 or V6    <Desc / Clms Page number 7>   whose input signals of a microphone 80 can be placed, the z. B. is set up in a sonicated by the load 9, which may be a loudspeaker. A filter 33 is connected downstream of the amplifier stage.       The influence of the route downstream of load 9 can also be recorded. Since the predictor 12 takes into account the behavior of the controlled system comprising the amplifier stage, constant feedback can be dispensed with.       12 shows the exemplary embodiment for the power section 5. The power section 5 is formed, for example, from the voltage supplies 41, 42 and a half-bridge arrangement 43, 44.      The half-bridge arrangement is formed from a main switch 50 and an anti-parallel free-wheeling diode 51 and a further main switch 52 with a further free-wheeling diode 53.       The output of the main switch 50 is connected to the input of the main switch 52 via a line 54. The input of the main switch 50 is connected to the voltage supply 41 via the supply line 55 and the output of the main switch 52 is connected to the voltage supply 42 via the supply line 56.       The voltage supply 42 is connected in series. The low-power signal train 4 is fed to the driver device 45. If the signal 4 is low, the point 48 is connected to the supply device 42 via the lower switch 44. B. 41.42 in which the power supply of a load, for. B. at the powerful output voltage 6, intermittently interrupted with low loss and / or reversed polarity.       The efficiency of the switching amplifier is significantly influenced by the switching frequency.      The switching losses of FET circuit breakers increase disproportionately with the voltage load. At least one low-frequency D amplifier stage V2 to V5 of an amplifier stage V6 supplies power for the bass loudspeakers, while the much smaller power for the tweeters is provided by another D amplifier stage V2 to V5 of the amplifier stage V6, which has a significantly higher switching frequency and smaller supply voltage works.       13 shows an example of the digital implementation of controller R1. The data words of a supplied target data stream 1, e.g. B. in i2s format, z. B. the converter 100 and the prefilter 102, which may also be designed as a decimation filter, may be serially fed to the adder or mixer 13. The data stream 1" is converted by the coding device 3 into the digital signal train 4 in such a way that the value of the signal train 4 averaged over the duration of a switching period follows the data stream 1 ".     The digital signal train 4 is amplified by a switching amplifier 5 (see also FIG. 12) to the high-performance output voltage 6, the control device 13 changing the switching time errors or changing the shape of the signal train 4 as a result of different switching times of the switching transistors 43, 44 of the power unit 5 compensated. The digital signal train 4, which corresponds to the data stream 1 ″, is taken over by the D-latch of the converter 100 on each rising edge of the clock signal 110. The converter 100 converts, for example, the digital signal trains of the target data stream 1 in synchronism with the clock signal 110    <Desc / Clms Page number 8>   i2s format into a parallel or serial data stream 101, which is converted by a pre-filter 102 into a data stream 1 'of different resolution and synchronicity.       This data stream 1 'is synchronous with the clock signal 140, for example 176 kHz. This is also the synchronicity of the compensation data stream 17, which is obtained by comparing the digital signal train 4 with the powerful output voltage 6. The counter 104 generates the switching frequency clock 140 with which the counter 108 is controlled or reset. The counter 104 and the RS flip-flop 106 are controlled (reset) by the clock 140. By means of counter 104 , Comparator 103, RS flip-flop 106 and clock 120, PWM modulation of the data stream 1 "is carried out.       Fig. 14 shows an embodiment for a D amplifier with sinusoidal current consumption.      The rectifier 62 is connected on the input side to the network 63 and on the output side to the input of the PFC. With sinusoidal current consumption, the PFC regulates the mean value of its output voltage between the lines 55, 56, to which the D amplifier 5, which is formed by the D stages 43, 44, is connected.
